name: Algu Rai Shastri
bio: Algu Rai Shastri emerged as a pivotal figure in India's struggle for freedom and nation-building. Shastri's journey from a village in Mau district to the corridors of power was marked by unwavering dedication. His activism began with the Non-Cooperation Movement, and he swiftly rose through the ranks, serving as Secretary of various Congress Committees and a Member of the United Provinces Legislative Assembly. A member of the All-India Congress Committee since 1928, Shastri combined Arya Samaj principles with socialist ideas, later shifting towards a more militant stance. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces he advocated for Hindi as the national language and critiqued the reliance on the Government of India Act, 1935. Post-independence, he served in the first Lok Sabha and held various roles, including as President of the Uttar Pradesh Congress Committee.

name: Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar
bio: Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar was a distinguished lawyer and served as the Advocate-General of Madras State from 1929 to 1944. He was awarded Knighthood in 1932, which he later surrendered. Ayyar was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras where he played a crucial role, serving on nine committees including the Drafting Committee. He made significant contributions to debates on citizenship, fundamental rights, and emergency proclamations.

name: Ammu Swaminathan
bio: Ammu Swaminathan was an important leader in both the Indian independence movement and the fight for women’s rights. She, alongside Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay and others, founded the Women's India Association in 1917. This organisation played a crucial role in advocating for women's suffrage and combating social injustices like child marriage. Swaminathan's activism continued as she joined the Indian National Congress in 1934 and participated in the Quit India Movement. In the Constituent Assembly, she championed fundamental rights and directive principles. Post-independence, she served in the first Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha. Additionally, she held leadership roles in the film and scouting sectors, becoming Vice President of the Federation of Film Societies and President of the Bharat Scouts and Guides from 1960 to 1965.

name: Annie Mascarene
bio: Annie Mascarene, from Trivandrum, was a pioneering force in Indian politics and education. With dual M.A. degrees in history and economics, she became a lecturer in Sri Lanka before returning to Trivandrum to earn a law degree. Mascarene's political journey saw her serve in the Travancore-Cochin Legislative Assembly from 1948 to 1952, where she briefly held the role of Minister for Health and Power. In the Constituent Assembly, she made notable contributions to discussions on the subject of federalism. She became the first independent woman candidate to be elected from Kerala Lok Sabha, where advocated vigorously for women's representation in politics.

name: Dr B. R. Ambedkar
bio: Dr Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar played a pivotal role in the Constituent Assembly. As Chairman of the Drafting Committee, he was instrumental in shaping the Constitution of India. Ambedkar’s profound understanding and leadership were evident through his extensive interventions and speeches, which significantly influenced the Assembly’s debates. He also submitted the "States and Minorities" report, outlining essential protections for Scheduled Castes. His meticulous work and advocacy earned him the title of the "Father of the Indian Constitution," reflecting his critical role in framing a just and inclusive legal framework for independent India.

name: Biswanath Das
bio: Born in Ganjam district, Biswanath Das obtained a law degree from Calcutta University and began practising law in Berhampur, where he advocated for tenant farmers. His political career began in the Madras Legislative Council, where he served from 1921 to 1930. After Ganjam merged with Odisha, Das became the Prime Minister of Odisha in 1936. A staunch advocate for India's independence, Das resigned from the Legislative Council to join the Salt Satyagraha and was imprisoned during the Quit India movement in 1942. Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress ticket, he contributed significantly to discussions on emergency provisions and revenue distribution. After independence, he served as Governor of Uttar Pradesh from 1962 to 1967 and became Chief Minister of Orissa in 1971, leading the United Front coalition until 1972.

name: Begum Qudsia Aizaz Rasul
bio: Begum Aizaz Rasul was a pioneering Indian politician and the only Muslim woman in the Constituent Assembly. Born into a princely family, she entered politics early and was elected to the U.P. Legislative Assembly in 1937, where she held significant positions, including Leader of the Opposition. Rasul strongly opposed the partition of India and feudal practices like the Zamindari system. Rasul was the only Muslim woman in the Constituent Assembly, contributing to discussions on national language and minority rights. After independence, she was elected to the Rajya Sabha and later the U.P. Legislative Assembly. She also championed women's hockey, leading the Indian Women’s Hockey Federation for two decades.

name: Brajeshwar Prasad
bio: Brajeshwar Prasad, an influential figure in Indian politics, founded the Civil Liberties Union (Gaya) in 1937. He played key roles in agriculture and labour movements, including the Khetihar Mazdoor Sangh. A prominent freedom fighter, Prasad actively participated in the Quit India Movement and other national movements, leading to his imprisonment in 1944. Prasead was elected as member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. During the debates in the Assembly he contributed to the discussions on citizenship, the preamble, Centre-State relations, and public health.

name: Dakshayani Velayudhan
bio: Dakshayani Velayudhan was a pioneering Dalit woman politician and activist from Kerala. Born into the Pulaya community, she defied oppressive caste norms from a young age. Velayudhan's activism was fueled by her family's involvement in Civil Disobedience and the. 1913 Kayal Sammelanam. Elected to the Constituent Assembly in 1946, she was the only Dalit woman member and one of the youngest at age of 34. Velayudhan made significant interventions, challenging the proposed centralization of power and advocating for substantial societal reforms. Post-independence, she served in the Provincial Parliament, continued her work for Dalit rights, and founded the Mahila Jagriti Parishad. The Kerala Government established an award in her honour in 2019.

name: Dr Rajendra Prasad
bio: Dr Rajendra Prasad was a prominent scholar, journalist, lawyer and freedom fighter. Prasad served as the President of the Constituent Assembly from 1946-1950. During the same time, he also chaired four committees of the Constituent Assembly. In 1950, Prasad became the first President of independent India. For his service to the nation he was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1962.

name: Frank Anthony
bio: Frank Anthony one of the prominent members of the Anglo-Indian community, who became the head of the All India Anglo-Indian Association in 1942. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar. Apart from being a member, he served as the temporary Vice President of the Constituent Assembly and he was also a part of the Advisory Committee and Sub-committee on Minorities. Post-Independence Anthony served as a nominated Anglo-Indian member of the Lok Sabha seven times.

name: G Durgabai
bio: G. Durgabai was a freedom fighter and public activist for women’s emancipation. In 1936, she founded the Andhra Mahila Sabha to support young Telugu girls in their education and edited the Telugu journal Andhra Mahila. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, she advocated for the national language, judicial independence, and human trafficking issues.

name: Gopinath Bardoloi
bio: Gopinath Bardoloi was the first Chief Minister of Assam. He played an integral role in setting up educational institutions and promoting Industrial growth in Assam. He was elected as a member of the Constitutional Assembly from Assam. In the Assembly he was the chairman of the sub-committee on North-East Frontier Tribal Areas and Assam Excluded & Partially Excluded Areas. He was the voice of tribal rights and representation in the Constituent Assembly.

name: H. V. Kamath
bio: Hari Vishnu Kamath had a successful career in the Indian Civil Service, serving in various roles until 1938, which he left to join the independence movement as General Secretary of Subhash Chandra Bose’s Forward Bloc. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, he became known for his bold and often eccentric interventions. He advocated for individual rights, democratic values, linguistic diversity, and a balanced federal system, while expressing concerns about emergency provisions and state power overreach. After falling out with Congress, he joined the Praja Socialist Party, winning a seat in India’s first Lok Sabha after a legal battle.

name: Hansa Mehta
bio: One of 15 women framers of the Constitution, Hansa Jivraj Mehta was a trailblazing figure in Indian politics and women’s rights. She studied philosophy and journalism in England, where she met Sarojini Naidu and Mahatma Gandhi. Mehta was elected to the Bombay Legislative Council in 1937 and played a pivotal role in drafting the Indian Women’s Charter of Rights and Duties. As a member of the Constituent Assembly, she advocated for women’s rights, intervened on issues like the uniform civil code. Later, she significantly contributed to the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights, ensuring inclusivity in Article 1. Mehta was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 1959.

name: Hriday Nath Kunzru
bio: Initially a Congress member, Kunzru later joined the National Liberation Federation, eventually becoming its President in 1934. His political career included roles in the Legislative Council of the United Provinces, the Central Legislative Assembly, and the Council of States. He was a moderate voice in the independence movement, advocating for self-governance without supporting Satyagraha or Non-Cooperation. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he contributed to debates on federalism and provincial governance. After independence, he served in the Rajya Sabha from 1952 to 1962 and was involved in the States Reorganisation Commission and the University Grants Commission.

name: J. J. M. Nichols-Roy
bio: James Joy Mohan Nichols-Roy was a politician from present day Meghalaya. He was the first tribal representative on the Assam Governor’s Council and was later elected to the Assam Legislative Assembly. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam. Nichols-Roy is known as the architect of the Sixth Schedule, he advocated in the Constituent Assembly for protection of the distinct society and culture of the hill tribes.

name: Jaipal Munda
bio: Jaipal Singh, was born into a Munda tribal family in Khunti, Bihar (now Jharkhand). He graduated from St. John’s College, Oxford post in 1928 and joined ICS, only to leave the service when he was called to captain the Indian Hockey team in the Olympics. He was one of the few independent candidates to have been elected to the Constituent Assembly. In the Assembly he advocated for the interests of tribal people, using the platform to address their concerns.

name: Jawaharlal Nehru
bio: Jawaharlal Nehru served as the country's first Prime Minister from 1947 to 1964. He actively led key movements such as the Non-Cooperation and Civil Disobedience Movements. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces on a Congress Party ticket, he played a crucial role in framing India's Constitution, notably delivering the Objectives Resolution. He held important positions in the various committees of the Assembly. Nehru's tenure as Prime Minister was marked by significant economic and educational reforms, establishing institutions like IITs and AIIMS. His legacy endures in India's democratic foundation.

name: Jerome D' Souza
bio: Jerome D’Souza was a Jesuit priest and educationalist. While not directly involved in the freedom movement, D’Souza contributed to post-war educational planning through the War Reconstruction Committee. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He made important interventions on various topics including language, minority rights and reservation. D’Souza played a key role in diplomatic negotiations for India, representing the government at the United Nations and engaging with the Vatican and French government. He founded the Xavier Board of Higher Education in India and the Indian Social Institute.

documents.name: Jerome Dsouza CAD Vol. II_21 January 1947

name: K. M. Munshi
bio: Kanhaiyalal Maneklal Munshi, was a notable lawyer, author, and social reformer. After completing his education at Baroda College, he practised law in Bombay and began writing historical fiction. Munshi joined the Indian National Congress in 1916 and actively participated in the freedom struggle, providing legal counsel to detained freedom fighters and engaging in movements like Bardoli Satyagraha and Quit India. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly and contributed significantly to debates on fundamental rights and minority protections. Post-Independence, he served as the Minister for Agriculture and Food, introducing the Van Mahotsav initiative to enhance forest cover. He later became the Governor of Uttar Pradesh from 1953 to 1957. Munshi also founded the Bhartiya Vidya Bhavan in 1938 to promote Indian culture and education.

documents.name: K M Munshi CAD Vol._ 17 May 1949
documents.src: ./documents/K. M. Munshi/K M Munshi CAD Vol._ 17 May 1949.pdf

name: K. Santhanam
bio: Kasturiranga Santhanam was a prominent lawyer practising at the Madras High Court. He was the first editor of the Indian Express from 1932 to 1940, later becoming joint editor of the Hindustan Times. Santhanam played a significant role in the Indian independence movement, participating in the Non-Cooperation and Satyagraha movements. He even organised khadi production efforts throughout Tamil Nadu from 1922 to 1930. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, he advocated for adult franchise, local governance, and citizenship. Post-independence, he served as Minister of State for Transport and later as Lieutenant Governor of Vindhya Pradesh.

documents.name: K. Santhanam CAD Vol. V_20 August 1947
documents.src: ./documents/K. Santhanam/K. Santhanam CAD Vol. V_20 August 1947.pdf

name: K. T. Shah
bio: K. T. Shah, a professor of economics, represented the Princely States at the Round Table Conference in 1930. In 1938, he was appointed as the General Secretary of the National Planning Committee of the Indian National Congress aimed at addressing unemployment, defence, poverty, and industrialization. Shah also served on the July 1946 Congress Experts Committee which prepared materials for the Constituent Assembly and drafted the original Objectives Resolution. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar on a Congress ticket, Shah passionately advocated for socialism and the presidential form of government in the Assembly.

name: M. R. Masani
bio: Minocher Rustom Masani was a prominent Parsi politician and advocate, known for his active role in India's independence movement. As a Congress member, he served as President of the Bombay Provincial Congress Committee and was Mayor of Bombay in 1943. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay, he contributed to discussions on fundamental rights and minorities. Post Independence Masani served as India's ambassador to Brazil from 1948 to 1949. He later founded the Swatantra Party along with C. Rajagopalachari. The party became the principal opposition party to the Congress in the Lok Sabha by 1967.

name: Maulana Hasrat Mohani
bio: Hasrat Mohani, in addition to being a prominent figure in India's independence movement, and a notable Urdu poet. Initially a Congress member, Mohani later joined the All-India Muslim League, though he opposed the Partition. He won the 1946 Provincial Assembly elections on Muslim League ticket. Mohani is famed for coining the revolutionary slogan “Inquilab Zindabad” and played a significant role in the Khilafat movement. Elected to the Constituent Assembly, he actively debated issues like federalism, reservations for minorities, and the abolition of the Zamindari system.

name: N. G. Ranga
bio: Nayakulu G. Ranga, an economist and social reformer, served as the economic advisor to the Madras Government (1929-30). He joined the All India Congress Committee in 1930 and was elected to the Central Legislative Assembly. Ranga was pivotal in abolishing the zamindari system in Andhra and founded the All India Kisan Congress in 1935. A follower of Gandhi, Ranga advocated for complete independence and opposed the Simon Commission and the First Round Table Conference. He was arrested in 1940 for supporting Subhash Chandra Bose. Elected to the Constituent Assembly, he contributed to discussions on decentralisation and emergency powers. After leaving Congress due to disagreements over land reforms, Ranga founded several political parties, including the Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party and the Swatantra Party

name: N Gopalaswami Ayyangar
bio: Narasimha Gopalaswami Ayyangar, a distinguished administrator, served in the Madras Civil Service before becoming the Prime Minister of Kashmir in 1937. Elected to the Council of States in 1943, Ayyangar was pivotal in the ‘Committee for the Indianization of Army’ and co-authored the Sapru Committee Report on Constitutional Reforms. Ayyangar was elected to the Constituent Assembly by the Madras Assembly, he was part of the Drafting Committee. He also was the chief architect of Article 370, which defined the special relationship of the state of Jammu and Kashmir with the Indian Union. He later served in Nehru's cabinet as Minister for Railways and Transport (1948-1952) and Defence Minister (1952-1953).

name: N. Madhava Rau
bio: Rau was a prominent Indian statesman, lawyer, and constitutional adviser. He served as Dewan of Mysore from 1941 to 1946 and participated in the Round Table Conferences and the drafting of the Government of India Act, 1935. Rao was a key figure in the Constituent Assembly, representing Orissa Princely States. As a member of the Drafting Committee, he contributed significantly to discussions on village panchayats and federalism. After independence, he served in the Provincial Parliament (1950-1951) before retiring from public life.

name: Narhar Vishnu Gadgil
bio: Narhar Vishnu Gadgil was a freedom fighter, writer and politician from Maharashtra. He was a pioneer of various social reform movements in Maharashtra in the 1930s and was elected to the Constitutional Assembly from Bombay. He contributed to various debates around the national language of India, the federal set-up of the nation and the discussion on the budget estimates of the Assembly. In 1958 he was also appointed the Governor of Punjab.

name: Purnima Banerjee
bio: Purnima Banerji was a dedicated Congress leader and activist from the United Provinces. She actively participated in the Indian freedom struggle alongside notable figures like Sucheta Kripalani and Vijaylakshmi Pandit. Banerji was a member of the Congress Socialist Party and the Indian National Congress. As Secretary of the Allahabad City Congress Committee, she focused on rural outreach, organising meetings with farmers and trade unions. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, she contributed to debates on the Preamble, preventive detention, and Rajya Sabha qualifications.

name: R. R. Sidhva
bio: Rustom K. Sidhva began his career as a clerk in the Post Office in Karachi and later became the president of the Sind and Baluchistan Postmen’s Union in the early 1900s. A lifelong member of the Indian National Congress (INC), he served as General Secretary of the 45th INC in 1932. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, Sidhva represented the minority Parsi community. He actively participated in debates on minority rights, linguistic issues, and the role of religion in public life, reflecting his commitment to these issues.

name: Renuka Ray
bio: Renuka Ray was a prominent freedom fighter, social reformer, and advocate for women’s rights. Educated at the London School of Economics, she returned to India and joined the All India Women’s Conference, for which she also served as a president, where she championed women’s rights. In 1943, she was nominated to the Central Legislative Assembly as a representative for Indian women and later became a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal. Post-independence, she was appointed Minister of Relief & Rehabilitation in West Bengal (1952-57) and a Lok Sabha MP from Malda. In 1959, she chaired the Renuka Ray Committee on Social Welfare and Welfare of Backward Classes, leaving a lasting impact on Indian social legislation.

name: S. Nagappa
bio: He joined the Congress in 1930 and won a general seat in the 1937 Madras Presidency elections representing Kurnool. He was dedicated to uplifting Scheduled Castes, establishing a free hostel for their students in Kurnool in 1938. Nagappa played a significant role in the India’s independence movement, being the first in Kurnool to offer individual satyagraha during the Civil Disobedience Movement Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress Party ticket, he contributed to debates on minority representation and reservations. Later, he contested elections in 1952 and 1967 but faced defeats both times.

name: Seth Govind Das
bio: Seth Govind Das was an active member of the Indian National Congress, actively participated in key movements such as the Non-Cooperation Movement, the protests against the Simon Commission, the Civil Disobedience Movement, and the Quit India Movement. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, where he contributed to debates on issues like the ban on cow slaughter, the national language, and the national anthem. A prominent Parliamentarian, he served as the pro-tem speaker in the Second, Third, Fourth, and Fifth Lok Sabhas.

name: Krishna Sinha
bio: Krishna Sinha, an influential figure in Bihar played a pivotal role in the Non-Cooperation, Satyagraha, and Civil Disobedience movements. He was elected as a member of the Legislative Council in 1927. He was appointed as the Premier of Bihar in 1946 a post he resigned in protest against British actions in World War II. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar,  Sinha actively participated in discussions on the Objective Resolutions introduced by Jawaharlal Nehru.

name: Syamaprasad Mookerji
bio: Syama Prasad Mookerjee was a prominent politician, academic, and member of the Constituent Assembly from Calcutta. Initially a member of the Indian National Congress, even elected to the Bengal state legislature as its member, Mookerjee resigned later due to ideological differences. He served as Vice-Chancellor of Calcutta University and became a key figure in Bengal politics, leading the opposition and later heading the All-India Hindu Mahasabha. In the Constituent Assembly, he was a vocal advocate for minority rights, regional languages, and opposed the Muslim League’s exclusion from the Assembly. Post-independence, Mookerjee founded the Bharatiya Jana Sangh and fiercely opposed Article 370. He died in custody in Kashmir in 1953.

name: Syed Mohammad Sa'adulla
bio: Syed Muhammad Sa'adulla was a lawyer and prominent leader of the Muslim League in Assam. He was one of the 28 Muslim League members who attended the proceedings of the Constituent Assembly. Notably, he was the sole Muslim League member on the Drafting Committee.

documents.name: Syed Mohammad Saadullah CAD Vol._ 9 November 1948
documents.src: ./documents/Syed Mohammad Sa'adulla/Syed Mohammad Saadullah CAD Vol._ 9 November 1948.pdf

name: Vallabhbhai J Patel
bio: Vallabhbhai Jhaverbhai Patel was one of the most prominent leaders of the freedom movement. His political journey began in 1917 with his election to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation, where he implemented major reforms in sanitation and education. As a prominent leader in the Indian independence movement, Patel was actively involved in the Non-Cooperation, Satyagraha, and Quit India movements, facing arrests for his activism. He served as President of the Indian National Congress during the 1931 Karachi session, where the historic Karachi Resolution was passed. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay. Patel focused on fundamental and minority rights during the constitution-making process. As India’s first Home Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, he played a crucial role in integrating the 565 princely states into the Union and organised relief efforts for refugees. His leadership earned him the title "Iron Man of India."

documents.name: Sardar Patel CAD Vol._12 October 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Vallabhbhai J Patel/Sardar Patel CAD Vol._12 October 1949.pdf

name: A. B. Latthe
bio: A. B. Latthe was a member of the Constituent Assembly, from 17 August 1947 to 26 October 1948.

name: A. P. Pattani
bio: A. P. Pattani was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Western India States. The iconic portrait of Mahatma Gandhi on display at the Central Hall was presented to the Constituent Assembly by A. P. Pattani on 28 August 1947.

name: A. Ramaswamy Mudaliar
bio: A. Ramaswamy Mudaliar was a prominent politician and statesman. He was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He served in various legislative bodies over the years, including the Madras Legislative Council from 1921 to 1926, the Council of States in 1930, the Central Legislative Assembly from 1931 to 1934, the Provisional Parliament from 1950 to 1952, and the Rajya Sabha from 1952 to 1962.

name: Abdul Aziz Khan Abdul Kadir
bio: Abdul Kadir Abdul Aziz Khan was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bombay.

name: Abdul Halim Ghuznavi
bio: Abdul Halim Ghuznavi was a distinguished Bengali leader and educationist, born into a prominent literary family in Tangail, in present day Bangladesh. Educated at St. Xavier’s College in Calcutta, Ghuznavi began his political career opposing the 1905 Bengal Partition and joined the Congress Party briefly, before going on to become a significant Muslim League figure. Elected to the Central Legislative Assembly in 1926, he held key positions in various committees, including the Railway Standing Finance Committee and the Federal Finance Committee. He actively participated in the Round Table Conferences and presided over the 1929 Muslim League Conference.

name: Abdul Hamid
bio: Abdul Hamid was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: Abdul Kadar Mohammad Shaikh
bio: Abdul Kadar Mohammad Shaikh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bombay.

name: Acharya Jugal Kishore
bio: Acharya Jugal Kishore was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: Acharya J. B. Kripalani
bio: Jiwatram Bhagwandas Kripalani, commonly known as Acharya Kripalani, was born in 1888 in Hyderabad, Sindh. He studied at D.J. Sindh College, Wilson College, and Ferguson College before starting his teaching career in 1912 at Muzaffarpur College, Bihar. He later became Principal of Gujarat Vidyapeeth. Kripalani was an active participant in the Indian independence movement, closely following Mahatma Gandhi. He joined the Indian National Congress in 1927 and took part in significant movements such as the Champaran Satyagraha, Non-Cooperation Movement, and Quit India Movement. He served as Congress President in 1946 but resigned due to internal differences. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he chaired the Sub-Committee on Fundamental Rights and contributed to discussions on the Preamble. In 1951, he founded the Krishak Mazdoor Praja Party, later merging with the Praja Socialist Party before retiring from politics. A critic of Indira Gandhi, he was arrested during the Emergency in 1975.

name: Achint Ram Lala
bio: Lala Achint Ram joined the Indian independence movement at a young age and became a member of the Indian National Congress. He was actively involved in various movements, including civil disobedience and the Quit India movement, leading to his imprisonment four times. Ram was a prominent leader in the Servants of India Society founded by Gopal Krishna Gokhale and held several administrative roles, including serving as General Secretary of the Punjab Congress and a member of the Congress Working Committee. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly East Punjab. Post-independence, he served as a Member of Parliament from Hisar in the first two Lok Sabhas. Along with his wife, he participated in Vinobha Bhave's Bhoodan movement. Ram passed away in 1961 during a land redistribution campaign, leaving behind a legacy of activism.

name: Akshay Kumar Das
bio: Akshay Kumar Das was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Assam.

name: Algu Rai Shastri
bio: Algu Rai Shastri emerged as a pivotal figure in India's struggle for freedom and nation-building. Shastri's journey from a village in Mau district to the corridors of power was marked by unwavering dedication. His activism began with the Non-Cooperation Movement, and he swiftly rose through the ranks, serving as Secretary of various Congress Committees and a Member of the United Provinces Legislative Assembly. A member of the All-India Congress Committee since 1928, Shastri combined Arya Samaj principles with socialist ideas, later shifting towards a more militant stance. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces he advocated for Hindi as the national language and critiqued the reliance on the Government of India Act, 1935. Post-independence, he served in the first Lok Sabha and held various roles, including as President of the Uttar Pradesh Congress Committee.

documents.name: Algurai Shastri CAD Vol. I_20 January 1947
documents.src: ./documents/Algu Rai Shastri/Algurai Shastri CAD Vol. I_20 January 1947.pdf

name: Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar
bio: Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar was a distinguished lawyer and served as the Advocate-General of Madras State from 1929 to 1944. He was awarded Knighthood in 1932, which he later surrendered. Ayyar was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras where he played a crucial role, serving on nine committees including the Drafting Committee. He made significant contributions to debates on citizenship, fundamental rights, and emergency proclamations.

name: Amiyo Kumar Ghosh
bio: Amiyo Kumar Ghosh was an Indian politician who served as a member of the Constituent Assembly representing Bihar. He also held a seat in the Bihar Legislative Assembly.

name: Ammu Swaminathan
bio: Ammu Swaminathan was an important leader in both the Indian independence movement and the fight for women’s rights. She, alongside Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay and others, founded the Women's India Association in 1917. This organisation played a crucial role in advocating for women's suffrage and combating social injustices like child marriage. Swaminathan's activism continued as she joined the Indian National Congress in 1934 and participated in the Quit India Movement. In the Constituent Assembly, she championed fundamental rights and directive principles. Post-independence, she served in the first Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha. Additionally, she held leadership roles in the film and scouting sectors, becoming Vice President of the Federation of Film Societies and President of the Bharat Scouts and Guides from 1960 to 1965.

documents.name: Ammu Swaminathan CAD Vol. XI_24 November 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Ammu Swaminathan/Ammu Swaminathan CAD Vol. XI_24 November 1949.pdf

name: Anugrahnarayan Sinha
bio: Anugrahnarayan Sinha popularly known as ‘Bihar Vibhuti’ was an ardent follower of Gandhi and led Satyagraha movements in Bihar. As a key member of the Congress Party, he helped organise the Gaya Congress in 1922. Sinha was involved in major political movements, including the Civil Disobedience movement (1930) and the Individual Satyagraha (1940), which led to his arrest. Sinha was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He remained a key figure in Bihar politics even after the independence and was elected to the first Bihar Legislative Assembly post-independence.

name: Arun Chandra Guha
bio: Arun Chandra Guha was a dynamic figure in India’s political and intellectual landscape. Born in Barisal, Bengal, Guha graduated from Braja Mohan College and established a publishing house, Saraswati Library, where he championed radical literature. A member of the Jugantar Party, he was frequently imprisoned for his revolutionary activities. Transitioning to mainstream politics, Guha joined the Indian National Congress and played a significant role in the non-cooperation movement, later becoming General Secretary of the West Bengal Pradesh Congress Committee. In the Constituent Assembly, he contributed notably to debates on constitutional drafts. Post-independence, Guha served as a Lok Sabha member and Minister of State for Finance during his first term in the Lok Sabha. He also chaired the Estimates Committee (1965-66), wherein he recommended changes to the functioning of the University Grants Commission and influenced higher education reforms.

name: Ari Bahadur Gurung
bio: Ari Bahadur Gurung was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: Ashutosh Mallick
bio: Ashutosh Mallick was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He also served as a member and Deputy Speaker of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly.

name: Awadesh Pratap Singh
bio: Awadhesh Pratap Singh was a prominent Indian freedom fighter and politician from Vindhya Pradesh. A committed Congress leader, he served on the Congress Constitution Framing Committee in 1935 and led the Mahakoshal PCC as President in 1937. He was the Prime Minister of Rewa State from May 1948 to April 1949 and Chief Minister of Vindhya Pradesh until April 1949. Singh served as a member of the Constituent Assembly, Provisional Parliament, and Rajya Sabha.

name: Aziz Ahmad Khan
bio: Aziz Ahmad Khan was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: B. Gopala Reddy
bio: B. Gopala Reddy was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He served in various legislative and ministerial positions at both the state and national level. He was a member of the Madras Legislative Assembly from 1937 to 1939 and again in 1946. He also served as a minister in the Madras government, holding portfolios for Local Administration and Finance from 1947 to 1952. After the formation of Andhra Pradesh, Reddy was a member of the state Legislative Assembly and served as the Chief Minister for a brief period. Reddy also served as a member of the Rajya Sabha from 1958 to 1962, and the Third Lok Sabha. He held various ministerial positions in the Union government. Later, he served as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh from May 1967 to June 1972.

name: B. H. Khardekar
bio: B. H. Khardekar was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Kolhapur State. He also served as a member of the First Lok Sabha.

name: B. L. Mitter
bio: B. L. Mitter was a prominent barrister, who held several important positions including his role as Advocate General of Bengal and Law Member in Viceroy's Executive Council. He led the Indian Delegation to the League of Nations in 1931 and 1933. He served as the Advocate-General of India from 1937 to 1945. In the Constituent Assembly, Mitter was a member representing Baroda and resigned from the Assembly on 13 September 1947. He also served as the Prime Minister of the erstwhile Baroda State.

name: B. Pattabhi Sitaramayya
bio: Bhogaraju Pattabhi Sitaramayya was a freedom fighter and doctor from Masulipatnam, Andhra Pradesh. In 1919, he founded the weekly English publication, Janmabhumi. Sitaramayya left his medical career in 1916 to actively engage in the Indian freedom movement, joining the Congress party and participating in key movements like the Home Rule movement, Salt Satyagraha, and Quit India. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the Madras province in 1946, he played a crucial role in negotiations for integrating princely states into India and chaired the Committee of Chief Commissioners’ Provinces, influencing the administrative setup for Delhi. His significant contributions included interventions on issues like the privy purse and separate electorates. Sitaramayya later served as Governor of Madhya Pradesh from 1952 to 1957.

name: B. Shiva Rao
bio: Benegal Shiva Rao, influenced by his older brother Sanjiva Rao and mentor Annie Besant, began his political journey as a sub-editor at Besant's New India in 1917. In the 1920s, he engaged in constitutional reform, working alongside Besant on the Commonwealth of India Bill and participating in the Indian Round Table Conference. As a trade union leader, he represented Indian workers at the International Labour Organisation Conference and led the National Trades Union Federation. From the 1930s, he wrote for The Hindu and The Manchester Guardian, connecting with key figures in the independence movement. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, Rao contributed significantly to the documentation of India's constitution-making process. He later served in India's first Lok Sabha and later in the Rajya Sabha.

name: B. L. Sondhi
bio: B. L. Sondhi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: B. M. Gupte
bio: Balachandra Maheshwar Gupte was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bombay.

name: B. N. Munavalli
bio: Basavaneppa N. Munavalli was educated in Dharwar and Poona and established his legal practice in Hubli, where he became a prominent advocate for citizens' rights. A key player in local movements, he led the Ramdurg Samsthan Prajasangha against oppressive land revenue policies and was arrested multiple times for his activism. Munavalli was elected to the Constituent Assembly from the Bombay States. He was also involved in the Karnataka unification movement and contested the 1957 Lok Sabha elections

name: B. P. Jhunjhunwala
bio: Banarsi Prasad Jhunjhunwala was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He was later elected to the 1st and 2nd Lok Sabha from Bhagalpur, Bihar.

name: B. R. Ambedkar
bio: Dr Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar played a pivotal role in the Constituent Assembly. As Chairman of the Drafting Committee, he was instrumental in shaping the Constitution of India. Ambedkar’s profound understanding and leadership were evident through his extensive interventions and speeches, which significantly influenced the Assembly’s debates. He also submitted the "States and Minorities" report, outlining essential protections for Scheduled Castes. His meticulous work and advocacy earned him the title of the "Father of the Indian Constitution," reflecting his critical role in framing a just and inclusive legal framework for independent India.

name: B. V. Keskar
bio: B. V. Keskar, born in Pune in 1903, was a distinguished figure in India's political and cultural realms. Educated at Kashi Vidyapith and Sorbonne, Paris, Keskar joined the Indian National Congress during the Non-Cooperation Movement of 1921 and served as Secretary in the Foreign Department and later as General Secretary of the party. He was elected to the Constituent from United Provinces. After independence, Keskar held several roles as Deputy Minister of External Affairs (1948-52), as well as Deputy Minister of Railways and Transport (1952), and later as Minister of Information and Broadcasting (1952-57). A passionate advocate for classical Indian music, he spearheaded initiatives like Vrinda Vadya and the National Programme of Music on All India Radio.

name: Babu Ramnarayan Singh
bio: Ramnarayan Singh known as ‘Chotanagpur Kesri,’ was a prominent freedom fighter from the Chotanagpur region. He served as Secretary and President of the Chatra Sub-Divisional Congress Committee, and briefly as Vice-Chairman of the Hazaribagh District Board. He was elected to the Central Legislative Assembly in 1927, he served until 1946 and was also a long-time member of the Bihar Pradesh Congress Committee. Singh was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He was distressed by the absence of Panchayats in the Constitution, and expressed discontent about party politics in India. Singh intervened in the debates on the fifth schedule and the role of civil servants in an independent India.

name: Bakshi Tek Chand
bio: Bakhshi Tek Chand, a Judge and Chief Justice of the Lahore High Court, joined the Congress in the early 1900s. He later served as a member of the Punjab Legislative Council. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab on a Congress Party ticket, Chand actively participated in debates advocating for personal liberty and the separation of powers. In 1949 he was appointed the Chairman to the Patents Enquiry Committee, which aimed to reform the existing patent system.

name: Baldev Singh Sardar
bio: Sardar Baldev Singh joined the Akali Party and worked with Sikh leader Tara Singh. He was elected to the Punjab Provincial Assembly in 1937 and served as the Development Minister from 1942 to 1946. Singh represented the Sikh community in negotiations with the Cripps Mission in 1942 and the Cabinet Mission in 1946, opposing partition and advocating for minority safeguards. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punja. Post-independence, Singh became India's first Defence Minister in the interim government under Jawaharlal Nehru, overseeing security and relief during partition.

name: Balwant Rai Gopalji Mehta
bio: Balwant Rai Gopalji Mehta born in Bhavnagar, Gujrat, he attended Samaldas College and Gujarat College but did not graduate due to his refusal to accept colonial recognition. Active in Congress politics since the 1920s, Mehta participated in key movements, including the Non-Cooperation and Quit India Movements. He played a significant role in the All-India States Peoples Conference and briefly served as Prime Minister of Bhavnagar State. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Saurashtra, he contributed to the Congress party's structure post-independence, eventually becoming Chief Minister of Gujarat in 1963. He played a significant role in the All-India States Peoples Conference and briefly served as Prime Minister of Bhavnagar State. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Saurashtra, he contributed to the Congress party's structure post-independence, eventually becoming Chief Minister of Gujarat in 1963.

name: Balwant Sinha Mehta
bio: A graduate of Fergusson College, Pune, Mehta emerged as a key figure in the Congress movement within Vindhya Pradesh. His dedication to social causes extended beyond politics, as he actively participated in caste-based organisations like the All India Adimjati Sewak Sangh and the All India Marwari Sammelan. Imprisoned twice for his participation in the freedom struggle, Mehta joined the Constituent Assembly in 1948, representing the United States of Rajasthan. After independence, Mehta was elected to India’s first Lok Sabha in 1952, representing Udaipur. He contributed to the Parliamentary Delimitation Committee for Rajasthan in 1951 and the Delimitation Commission of India in 1953.

name: Balkrishna Sharma
bio: Balkrishna Sharma was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

documents.name: Balkrishna Sinha CAD Vol. IV_15 July 1947
documents.src: ./documents/Balkrishna Sharma/Balkrishna Sinha CAD Vol. IV_15 July 1947.pdf

name: Banshi Dhar Misra
bio: Banshi Dhar Mishra was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: Basanta Kumar Das
bio: Basanta Kumar Das was a freedom fighter from West Bengal who played a significant role in India’s independence movement. Born in Ramchan village, he graduated from Presidency College, Calcutta, and joined a revolutionary group during his student days. In 1921, Das became a member of the Indian National Congress and was arrested six times for participating in freedom movements like the Non-Cooperation, Civil Disobedience, and Quit India movements. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal, Das contributed to debates on the Assembly's authority. Post-independence, he was active in the Provisional Parliament, the First Lok Sabha, and the West Bengal Legislative Council. He also led agricultural delegations and worked on educational and rehabilitation committees, leaving a lasting impact on post-colonial India.

name: Binodanand Jha
bio: Binodanand Jha joined the freedom movement after Mahatma Gandhi’s call for freedom in 1919. He led the Non-Cooperation, Civil Disobedience, and Quit India movements in the Santhal Pargana region. Jha was elected to the Constituent Assembly in 1948 from Bihar on a Congress ticket. Post-independence he joined the Bihar Legislature, even became the third Chief Minister of Bihar in in 1961

name: Biswanath Das
bio: Born in Ganjam district, Biswanath Das obtained a law degree from Calcutta University and began practising law in Berhampur, where he advocated for tenant farmers. His political career began in the Madras Legislative Council, where he served from 1921 to 1930. After Ganjam merged with Odisha, Das became the Prime Minister of Odisha in 1936. A staunch advocate for India's independence, Das resigned from the Legislative Council to join the Salt Satyagraha and was imprisoned during the Quit India movement in 1942. Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress ticket, he contributed significantly to discussions on emergency provisions and revenue distribution. After independence, he served as Governor of Uttar Pradesh from 1962 to 1967 and became Chief Minister of Orissa in 1971, leading the United Front coalition until 1972.

name: Bodhram Dube
bio: Bodhram Dube was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Orissa. He was a member of the Orissa Legislative Assembly from 1937 to 1939 and again from 1946 to 1948. During his tenure, he also served as a Minister in the Government of Orissa from 1937 to 1939. Later, Dube became a member of the the Rajya Sabha serving from 3 April 1952 to 2 April 1958.

name: Boniface Lakra
bio: Boniface Lakra represented Bihar in the Constituent Assembly. He had earlier been elected as a member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly.

name: Brijlal Nandlal Biyani
bio: Brijlal Nandlal Biyani was an Indian freedom fighter and writer, popularly known as Vidarbha Kesari. Influenced by Mahatma Gandhi, Biyani participated actively in the Non-Cooperation Movement, the Civil Disobedience Movement, and the Quit India Movement, facing imprisonment four times. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces & Berar. In recognition of his contributions, the Brijlal Biyani Science College in Amravati was named after him, and the Government of India issued a postage stamp in his honour in 2002.

name: Brajeshwar Prasad
bio: Brajeshwar Prasad, an influential figure in Indian politics, founded the Civil Liberties Union (Gaya) in 1937. He played key roles in agriculture and labour movements, including the Khetihar Mazdoor Sangh. A prominent freedom fighter, Prasad actively participated in the Quit India Movement and other national movements, leading to his imprisonment in 1944. Prasead was elected as member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. During the debates in the Assembly he contributed to the discussions on citizenship, the preamble, Centre-State relations, and public health.

name: C. M. Poonacha
bio: Cheppudira Muthanna Poonacha was a prominent leader of the Indian freedom struggle. He was actively involved in various movements, facing imprisonment during the Salt Satyagraha and the Quit India movement. He was a significant political figure in Coorg, serving as Secretary of the Coorg District Congress Committee and later as the leader of the Congress in the Coorg Legislative Council, where he was elected in 1945. Poonacha even represented Coorg in the Constituent Assembly. After independence, he became Coorg's first and last Chief Minister following its merger with Mysore State in 1956.

name: C. Perumalswami Reddi
bio: C. Perumalswami Reddi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: C. Rajagopalachari
bio: C. Rajagopalachari, popularly referred to as 'Rajaji' was a statesman and a Gandhian. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras. In the Assembly, he intervened on the issues of religious freedom and citizenship. Post-independence, he served as the last Governor-General of India till 1950.

name: C. Subramaniam
bio: Chidambaram Subramaniam was a prominent leader and lawyer from Madras. He began his career as a lawyer before venturing into politics with the Indian National Congress. There he held key positions including President of the Coimbatore District Congress Committee and member of the State Congress Working Committee. Subramaniam played an active role in India’s independence struggle, notably participating in the Quit India movement, which led to his imprisonment in 1932 and 1941. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, where he contributed to debates on freedom of trade and commerce. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, where he contributed to debates on trade and commerce. Post-independence, he served in the Madras Legislative Assembly and the Lok Sabha, holding important Cabinet positions in Steel and Mines, Agriculture, Finance, and Defence. As Agriculture Minister, he initiated the Green Revolution, significantly boosting India's food production. He was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1998.

name: C. S. Venkatachar
bio: C. S. Venkatachar was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Jodhpur.

name: Chaudhri Kamala
bio: Kamala Chaudhri was a freedom fighter, politician, and writer from Lucknow. Despite familial resistance, she excelled in Hindi literature and became an active member of the Indian National Congress. She participated in the Civil Disobedience Movement and was arrested multiple times. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces in 1946, she later served in the Provisional Parliament and the Lok Sabha, representing Hapur in 1962. Chaudhri was a strong advocate for women’s education and employment, particularly promoting Khadi and village industries.

name: Chaudhri Ranbir Singh
bio: Chaudhri Ranbir Singh was a prominent leader of the freedom struggle from Punjab. For his participation in Satyagraha and Quit India movements he was arrested multiple times. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab, there he intervened on a variety of issues like Delhi’s provincial autonomy, minimum economic price of agricultural produce, and Profession Tax. He is the only person to have served as a member of seven different legislative houses including the Constituent Assembly and Provincial Legislature.

name: Chaudhuri Mohd. Hassan
bio: Chaudhuri Mohd. Hassan was a member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: Chimanlal Chakubhai Shah
bio: Shah was a distinguished Congress leader and legal expert from Saurashtra. A prominent solicitor with the Government of Bombay, Shah was actively involved in municipal and legislative affairs. He served as a member of the Bombay Municipal Corporation and contributed to the Committee on Shops and Establishments Act. He was elected to the Lok Sabha in 1952.

name: Chaman Lall
bio: Chaman Lall was a distinguished Indian diplomat, politician, and author. Born in 1904, he played a significant role in India's early diplomatic missions, including serving as the first Indian Ambassador to Turkey. Lall was a member of the Indian National Congress and actively participated in the freedom struggle. His contributions extended to literature, where he authored several books and articles on international relations and India's foreign policy. Lall's career was marked by his dedication to fostering India's global presence and his advocacy for peace and cooperation in international affairs.

name: Chaturbhuj Pathak
bio: Chaturbhuj Pathak was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Central India States Group.

name: Chunnilal Purshottamdas Shah
bio: Chunnilal Purshottamdas Shah was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Baroda.

name: Dakshayani Velayudhan
bio: Dakshayani Velayudhan was a pioneering Dalit woman politician and activist from Kerala. Born into the Pulaya community, she defied oppressive caste norms from a young age. Velayudhan's activism was fueled by her family's involvement in Civil Disobedience and the. 1913 Kayal Sammelanam. Elected to the Constituent Assembly in 1946, she was the only Dalit woman member and one of the youngest at age of 34. Velayudhan made significant interventions, challenging the proposed centralization of power and advocating for substantial societal reforms. Post-independence, she served in the Provincial Parliament, continued her work for Dalit rights, and founded the Mahila Jagriti Parishad. The Kerala Government established an award in her honour in 2019.

name: Damber Singh Gurung
bio: Damber Singh Gurung was a prominent Gorkha leader, who was associated with the All India Gorkha League. He was a Member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He died on 7 April 1948.

name: Damodar Swarup Seth
bio: Damodar Swarup Seth was born in February 1896 in Bareilly, Uttar Pradesh. He completed his education at Government High School and Reid Christian College in Lucknow. A prominent figure in the Indian freedom struggle, Seth was arrested multiple times, notably for his involvement in the 1925 Kakori Conspiracy Case. He held key roles in various political organisations, including the All India Congress Committee, and served as Secretary of the Congress Socialist Party in 1935 and President of the UP Congress Committee in 1946. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces on a Congress ticket, Seth focused on Fundamental Rights and advocated for a new Constituent Assembly.

name: D. P. Khaitan
bio: D. P. Khaitan was a reputed lawyer and statesman. He was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He played a prominent role in the framing of the Constitution as a member of the Drafting Committee. However, he died in 1948, before the Constitution was enacted.

name: Dayal Das Bhagat
bio: Dayal Das Bhagat was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: Deshbandhu Gupta
bio: Rati Ram Gupta was honoured with the title ‘Deshbandhu’ by M. K. Gandhi and Swami Shradhanand. He engaged with revolutionary leaders and campaigned for the separation of Haryana from Punjab, advocating for Dalit upliftment and the abolition of untouchability. Gupta served seven years in the Punjab Legislative Assembly and was profoundly impacted by the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, which led to his participation in the Quit India movement, leading to his arrest. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Delhi on a Congress ticket, he advocated for print media and sought for greater Delhi representation in Parliament. He co-founded the newspaper Rozana Tej and later acquired The Indian News Chronicle, which was renamed Indian Express after his death in 1951.

name: Deshmukh P. S.
bio: Punjabrao S. Deshmukh, also known as Babusaheb Deshmukh, was an influential figure in India’s independence movement and a champion of farmers' rights. He founded the C. P. & Berar Farmers’ Association and actively participated in protests against untouchability. A prominent member of the Constituent Assembly, he contributed to discussions on citizenship and federalism. Post-independence, Deshmukh served as the Union Minister of Agriculture and was elected to the Lok Sabha for two terms between 1952 and 1962.

name: Dhananjoy Roy
bio: Dhananjoy Roy was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Dharam Dass A.
bio: A. Dharam Dass was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces. He was also a member of the Rajya Sabha for two terms between 1952 and 1960.

name: Dharanidhar Basu Matari
bio: Dharanidhar Basu Matari was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam. Post-Independence he was elected to the Lok Sabha from Kokrajhar constituency in Assam between 1957-1977.

name: Dharam Prakash
bio: Dharam Prakash was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Dhirendra Nath Datta
bio: Dhirendra Nath Datta was a member of the Bengal Legislative Council in 1946. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bengal and served as a member from 1946 to 1947.

name: Dip Narayan Sinha
bio: Dip Narayan Sinha was a Judge in the Calcutta High Court. He was a member of the Constituent Assembly.

name: Durbar Gopaldas A. Desai
bio: Desai was a prince who embraced the freedom struggle under Mahatma Gandhi’s influence. He renounced royal symbols and joined the Swaraj movement, serving as President of the Kheda District Local Board. Gopaldas participated in key movements like the Nagpur Flag Satyagraha (1922) and the Borsad Satyagraha (1923), facing multiple imprisonments. A pivotal figure in the Bardoli Satyagraha, Gopaldas was arrested during the Dandi March (1930) and the Quit India Movement (1942). In the Constituent Assembly, he represented Kathiawar States and contributed to discussions on the rights and welfare of princely states. He also presided over the Haripura Congress session in 1938.

name: Durbar Govinda Doss
bio: Doss was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: Hansa Mehta
bio: One of 15 women framers of the Constitution, Hansa Jivraj Mehta was a trailblazing figure in Indian politics and women’s rights. She studied philosophy and journalism in England, where she met Sarojini Naidu and Mahatma Gandhi. Mehta was elected to the Bombay Legislative Council in 1937 and played a pivotal role in drafting the Indian Women’s Charter of Rights and Duties. As a member of the Constituent Assembly, she advocated for women’s rights, intervened on issues like the uniform civil code. Later, she significantly contributed to the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights, ensuring inclusivity in Article 1. Mehta was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 1959.

documents.name: Hansa Mehta CAD Vol. I_18 December 1946
documents.src: ./documents/Hansa Mehta/Hansa Mehta CAD Vol. I_18 December 1946.pdf

documents.name: Hansa Mehta CAD Vol. V_14 Aug 1947
documents.src: ./documents/Hansa Mehta/Hansa Mehta CAD Vol. V_14 Aug 1947.pdf

name: V. I. Munishwamy Pillay
bio: V. I. Munishwamy Pillay was an activist committed to the empowerment of Scheduled Castes who faced economic challenges that limited his formal education. He began his career as a clerk before establishing his own business in 1925. Pillay served on the Madras Legislative Council in 1926 as a representative of the Depressed Classes and played a significant role in the All India Depressed Classes Federation, including signing the Poona Pact in 1932. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from the Madras Presidency on a Congress party ticket, where he advocated for the welfare of the Dalit community. Following independence, he served as a cabinet minister in the Provisional Parliament under Jawaharlal Nehru.

name: Frank Anthony
bio: Frank Anthony one of the prominent members of the Anglo-Indian community, who became the head of the All India Anglo-Indian Association in 1942. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar. Apart from being a member, he served as the temporary Vice President of the Constituent Assembly and he was also a part of the Advisory Committee and Sub-committee on Minorities. Post-Independence Anthony served as a nominated Anglo-Indian member of the Lok Sabha seven times.

documents.name: Frank Anthony CAD Vol. I_17 December 1946
documents.src: ./documents/Frank Anthony/Frank Anthony CAD Vol. I_17 December 1946.pdf

name: Gaganvihari Lalubhai Mehta
bio: Gaganvihari Lalubhai Mehta was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Western India and Gujarat States. He served as India's Ambassador to the United States from 1952 to 1958. He was awarded the Padma Vibhushan in 1959.

name: Gopinath Bardoloi
bio: Gopinath Bardoloi was the first Chief Minister of Assam. He played an integral role in setting up educational institutions and promoting Industrial growth in Assam. He was elected as a member of the Constitutional Assembly from Assam. In the Assembly he was the chairman of the sub-committee on North-East Frontier Tribal Areas and Assam Excluded & Partially Excluded Areas. He was the voice of tribal rights and representation in the Constituent Assembly.

documents.name: Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IV_18 July 1947
documents.src: ./documents/Gopinath Bardoloi/Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IV_18 July 1947.pdf

documents.name: Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_5 August 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Gopinath Bardoloi/Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_5 August 1949.pdf

documents.name: Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_6 September 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Gopinath Bardoloi/Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_6 September 1949.pdf

documents.name: Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_7 September 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Gopinath Bardoloi/Gopinath Bardoloi CAD Vol. IX_7 September 1949.pdf

name: H. Chandrasekharaiya
bio: H. Chandrasekharaiya was a prominent lawyer and politician in India. He practiced law from 1923 to 1941 and served as a Member of the Mysore Legislative Council from 1924 to 1941. He made history as the first non-official President of the Legislative Council, holding the position from 1941 to 1945. In the post-independence era, Chandrasekharaiya contributed significantly to education as the Minister for Education in Mysore from 1947 to 1951. He became a member of the  Constituent Assembly in 1947.

name: H. P. Mody
bio: H. P. Mody was a distinguished Indian politician and statesman known for his significant contributions to the country's legislative and executive spheres during the pre- and post-independence eras. Serving as a Member of the Central Legislative Assembly from 1929 to 1943. His expertise and leadership were further recognized with his appointment as a Member of the Viceroy's Executive Council from 1941 to 1943. After India gained independence, Mody played a pivotal role in shaping the new nation as a Member of the Constituent Assembly from 1948 to 1949. His exemplary service continued as he became the Governor of Uttar Pradesh, serving from May 2, 1949, to June 1, 1952.

name: H. Sitaram Reddi
bio: H. Sitaram Reddi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He also served as a member of the First Lok Sabha.

name: H. V. Kamath
bio: Hari Vishnu Kamath had a successful career in the Indian Civil Service, serving in various roles until 1938, which he left to join the independence movement as General Secretary of Subhash Chandra Bose’s Forward Bloc. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, he became known for his bold and often eccentric interventions. He advocated for individual rights, democratic values, linguistic diversity, and a balanced federal system, while expressing concerns about emergency provisions and state power overreach. After falling out with Congress, he joined the Praja Socialist Party, winning a seat in India’s first Lok Sabha after a legal battle.

documents.name: H. V. Kamath CAD Vol. IV_16 July 1947
documents.src: ./documents/H. V. Kamath/H. V. Kamath CAD Vol. IV_16 July 1947.pdf
documents.thumbnail: ./images/H. V. Kamath CAD Vol. IV_16 July 1947.jpg

name: Haji Abdul Sathar Haji Ishaq Sait
bio: Haji Abdul Sathar Haji Ishaq Sait was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: Hari Singh Gour
bio: Hari Singh Gour was a distinguished barrister born on November 26, 1872. He served as a delegate to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Indian Reforms in 1933 and chaired the Quinquennial Conference of the Universities of the Empire in 1936. Gour was a member of the Central Legislative Assembly from 1920 to 1934 and played a pivotal role in the Constituent Assembly.

documents.name: Hari Singh Gour CAD Vol. I-19 December 1946
documents.src: ./documents/Hari Singh Gour/Hari Singh Gour CAD Vol. I-19 December 1946.pdf
documents.thumbnail: ./images/Hari Singh Gour CAD Vol. I-19 December 1946.jpg

name: Hem Chandra Naskar
bio: Hem Chandra Naskar was a prominent Indian politician who played a significant role in the early 20th-century legislative and political landscape of Bengal and India. He served as a Member of the Bengal Legislative Council from 1921 to 1929, demonstrating his commitment to regional governance and legislative processes. In 1937, he was elected to the Bengal Legislative Assembly, further solidifying his influence in Bengal's political arena. His contributions extended to the national level as he became a Member of the Constituent Assembly of India, participating in the crucial task of drafting the Indian Constitution. In 1947, Hem Chandra Naskar was appointed as the Minister-in-Charge of Forests & Fisheries in West Bengal, where he oversaw significant developments in these sectors during the formative years of independent India.

name: Hirday Nath Kunzru
bio: Initially a Congress member, Kunzru later joined the National Liberation Federation, eventually becoming its President in 1934. His political career included roles in the Legislative Council of the United Provinces, the Central Legislative Assembly, and the Council of States. He was a moderate voice in the independence movement, advocating for self-governance without supporting Satyagraha or Non-Cooperation. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he contributed to debates on federalism and provincial governance. After independence, he served in the Rajya Sabha from 1952 to 1962 and was involved in the States Reorganisation Commission and the University Grants Commission.

name: J. C. Majumdar
bio: J. C. Majumdar was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: J. J. M. Nichols-Roy
bio: James Joy Mohan Nichols-Roy was a politician from present day Meghalaya. He was the first tribal representative on the Assam Governor’s Council and was later elected to the Assam Legislative Assembly. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam. Nichols-Roy is known as the architect of the Sixth Schedule, he advocated in the Constituent Assembly for protection of the distinct society and culture of the hill tribes.

documents.name: J.J.M. Nichols Roy CAD Vol. IX_8 August 1949
documents.src: ./documents/J. J. M. Nichols-Roy/J.J.M. Nichols Roy CAD Vol. IX_8 August 1949.pdf

documents.src: ./documents/J. J. M. Nichols-Roy/J.J.M. Nichols-Roy CAD Vol. IV_18 July 1947.pdf

documents.src: ./documents/J. J. M. Nichols-Roy/J.J.M. Nichols-Roy CAD Vol. IX_5 August 1949.pdf
