documents.src: ./documents/J. J. M. Nichols-Roy/J.J.M. Nichols-Roy CAD Vol. VII_8 November 1948.pdf

name: Jayendra Singh Jue Dev
bio: Jayendra Singh Jue Dev was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Central India States Group.

name: K. Chandramouli
bio: K. Chandramouli was an Indian politician who served as a Member of the Madras Legislative Assembly during the crucial years of 1937 and 1946. His dedication to public service and governance was further exemplified through his significant role as a Member of the Constituent Assembly from 1946 to 1948. Chandramouli's contributions were instrumental in shaping the legislative framework of both the Madras region and the newly independent India.

name: K. M. Munshi
bio: Kanhaiyalal Maneklal Munshi, was a notable lawyer, author, and social reformer. After completing his education at Baroda College, he practised law in Bombay and began writing historical fiction. Munshi joined the Indian National Congress in 1916 and actively participated in the freedom struggle, providing legal counsel to detained freedom fighters and engaging in movements like Bardoli Satyagraha and Quit India. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly and contributed significantly to debates on fundamental rights and minority protections. Post-Independence, he served as the Minister for Agriculture and Food, introducing the Van Mahotsav initiative to enhance forest cover. He later became the Governor of Uttar Pradesh from 1953 to 1957. Munshi also founded the Bhartiya Vidya Bhavan in 1938 to promote Indian culture and education.

documents.name: K M Munshi CAD Vol._ 17 May 1949
documents.src: ./documents/K. M. Munshi/K M Munshi CAD Vol._ 17 May 1949.pdf

name: K. M. Panikkar
bio: K. M. Panikkar was a distinguished Indian statesman and scholar who held several key positions throughout his career. He served as a Minister in the erstwhile Patiala State from 1933 to 1938 and in the Bikaner State later becoming the Chief Minister of Bikaner State, a role he held from 1944 until 1948. His diplomatic career included appointments as Ambassador to China, Egypt and other Arab countries, and France. , he was a member of the Rajya Sabha from August 25, 1959, to April 2, 1960, and from April 3, 1960, to May 22, 1961. An accomplished author, Panikkar wrote numerous books in both English and Malayalam.

name: K. N. Katju
bio: Kailash Nath Katju was a prominent Indian freedom fighter, lawyer, and politician. Katju was an active member of the Indian National Congress and later became a leading figure in post-independence India. He served as the Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh (then known as the Central Provinces and Berar) and held important positions in the Indian government, including that of a Union Minister. Katju was also a member of the Constituent Assembly that drafted the Indian Constitution. Known for his legal acumen, he contributed significantly to the legal and political landscape of the country.

name: Kaluram Virulkar
bio: Kaluram Virulkar was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madhya Bharat.

name: Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan
bio: Popularly known as Frontier Gandhi and Badshah Khan; took a prominent part in the anti-Rowlatt Act agitation; joined the Non-cooperation movement; formed Red shirt volunteer corps known as “Khudai Khidmatgar” (Servant of God); started a monthly capped ‘Pakhtoon’ which became the mouthpiece of Khudai Khidmatgars, 1928; Member, Congress Working Committee; Arrested and imprisoned under Defence of India Rufes, August 1942; Member, Constituent Assembly of undivided India, on partition his membership was transferred to the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan; Awarded Prisoner of the year, Amnesty International, 1962; awarded the ‘Nehru Peace Prize’, 1969; awarded Bharat Ratna, 1987.

name: Khan Bahadur Pheroze Kothawala
bio: Khan Bahadur Pheroze Kothawala was a distinguished Indian civil servant and legal practitioner. He practiced law at the Bombay High Court from 1912 to 1915 before being appointed as Private Secretary to His Highness the Maharaja of Rajpipla in 1916. Kothawala served as the Dewan of Rajpipla from November 1930, playing a key administrative role. A prominent political figure, he was elected multiple times to the Minister's Committee of the Chamber of Princes, representing the Gujarat States Group in 1939, 1942, 1944, and 1946. He also contributed to the shaping of modern India as a member of the Constituent Assembly.

name: Kiran Shankar Roy
bio: Kiran Shankar Roy was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Lal Thakur Lal Singh
bio: Thakur Lal Singh was a freedom fighter and political leader from Madhya Pradesh. A freedom fighter, he represented the Bhopal State in the Constituent Assembly. There he supported the inclusion of rural and agricultural interests in India's Constitution, reflecting his commitment to the welfare of farmers and rural communities.

name: Lal Shiva Bahadur Singh
bio: Lal Shiva Bahadur Singh  was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Rewa. He also served as Minister for Industries of Vindhya Pradesh.

name: Lal Yadhendra Singh
bio: Lal Yadhendra Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Rewa.

name: Leela Roy
bio: Leela Roy was Dhaka University’s first female student to earn a Master’s degree and was also actively involved in the women’s suffrage movement. She understood the necessity of education for women to secure financial security and take up a bigger role in shaping society for which she established Deepali Sangha, a women’s association,  in 1923. Leela Roy was nominated to the Constituent Assembly in 1946, where she strongly opposed and was deeply anguished by the idea of Partition. After learning about the inevitability of Partition, she resigned from the Assembly. Leela Roy participated intensely in relief efforts in the wake of communal violence which broke out during the Partition and led various rehabilitation and rescue efforts to help refugees procure documentation.

name: Latifur Rahman
bio: Latifur Rahman was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He was involved in the formation of the Bihar Legislative Democratic Party.

name: M. A. Kazmi
bio: Mohammad Ahmad Kazmi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: M. A. Sreenivasan
bio: M. A. Sreenivasan was a prominent Indian leader and public servant who played a significant role in the political and economic landscape of Mysore and India. He served as the Trade Commissioner of Mysore in London, where he represented the interests of the princely state. As Minister for Industries, Agriculture, Food, and Civil Supplies in the Princely State of Mysore, he contributed to the development of key sectors in the region. Known as a leading voice for the cooperative sector, he worked to strengthen its influence across the country. Sreenivasan was also the Founder President of the Greater Mysore Chamber of Commerce and Industry (1976–79). A key figure in India's independence movement, he was a member of the Constituent Assembly from 1947 to 1948, where he helped shape the nation's future.

name: M. Asaf Ali
bio: M. Asaf Ali was a distinguished Indian politician and diplomat. He served as a Member of the Delhi Legislative Assembly in 1935 and was re-elected in 1945. Ali played a significant role in India's political landscape, holding key positions such as a Member of the Interim Government from September 2, 1946, to January 7, 1947, and a Member of the Constituent Assembly. He became India's first Ambassador to Washington, serving from February 1947 to April 1948. Ali later served as the Governor of Orissa from 1948 to 1952 and as India's Ambassador to Switzerland from 1952 to 1953.

name: M. R. Jayakar
bio: M. R. Jayakar was a prominent lawyer, scholar, and politician in early 20th-century India. A passionate advocate for Swaraj, he was a founding member of the Swaraj Party. He began his legal career as an advocate at the Bombay High Court in 1905. Jayakar played a pivotal role in the academic landscape, serving as the founder and first Vice-Chancellor of the University of Poona. He was also an influential member of the Bombay Legislative Council from 1923 to 1925 and later a member of the Central Legislative Assembly. In 1937, he was appointed as a judge of the Federal Court of India and was a key member of the Constituent Assembly that framed India's Constitution.

name: M. R. Masani
bio: Minocher Rustom Masani was a prominent Parsi politician and advocate, known for his active role in India's independence movement. As a Congress member, he served as President of the Bombay Provincial Congress Committee and was Mayor of Bombay in 1943. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay, he contributed to discussions on fundamental rights and minorities. Post Independence Masani served as India's ambassador to Brazil from 1948 to 1949. He later founded the Swatantra Party along with C. Rajagopalachari. The party became the principal opposition party to the Congress in the Lok Sabha by 1967.

documents.name: M. R. Masani CAD Vol. I_17 December 1946
documents.src: ./documents/M. R. Masani/M. R. Masani CAD Vol. I_17 December 1946.pdf
documents.thumbnail: ./images/M. R. Masani CAD Vol. I_17 December 1946.jpg

name: M. Satyanarayana
bio: Moturi Satyanarayana was a distinguished Congress leader. He joined the Dakshina Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha founded by Mahatma Gandhi. A fervent follower of Mahatma Gandhi, Satyanarayana actively participated in the Quit India movement and promoted Hindi through his editorial work. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras on an Indian National Congress ticket, he championed Hindustani as India's national language and played a key role in making Hindi one of the official languages. From 1950 to 1952, he was an MP in the Provisional Parliament and later served two terms in the Rajya Sabha from 1954 to 1966. He contributed to various cultural and educational institutions and received the Padma Shri in 1958 and Padma Bhushan in 1962.

name: Madhav Shrihari Aney
bio: Dr M. S. Aney was an educationist, freedom fighter, Sanskrit poet, statesman and politician and one of the founders of Congress Nationalist Party. He became a member of the Constituent Assembly, representing the Princely States of Central India in 1948.

name: Mahboob Ali Baig Sahib
bio: Mahboob Ali Baig Sahib was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: Mahavir Tyagi
bio: Mahavir Tyagi was a notable Congress leader from Uttar Pradesh. He received informal education and served in the British Indian Army before joining the independence movement post-Jallianwala Bagh massacre. A staunch follower of Gandhi, Tyagi actively participated in the Non-Cooperation Movement and Kisan movements, facing multiple imprisonments for his activism. In the Constituent Assembly he engaged in discussions on detention, taxation, and emergency powers. Tyagi was a member of the United Provinces Legislative Assembly and the All-India Congress Committee, and later served as a Member of Parliament and Minister of Revenue.

name: Mahesh Prasad Sinha
bio: Mahesh Prasad Sinha was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar.

name: Malati Chowdhury
bio: Malati Choudhury had a strong sense of patriotism and service which she developed during her education at Santiniketan. She moved to Orissa after completing her education and became an active part of the independence movement, participating in the Congress’ call for ‘Purna Swaraj’ (complete independence).She toured villages extensively to understand the daily lives and grievances of people and was later elected to the Orissa State Legislative Assembly. In 1946, Malati became the only woman from Orissa to be nominated to the Constituent Assembly but felt she could serve the nation better on the field, conducting rehabilitation work. She resigned from the Assembly soon after to focus on relief work, which she continued even after India’s independence.

name: Mannu Lal Dwivedi
bio: Mannu Lal Dwivedi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United States of Vindhya Pradesh.

name: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad
bio: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was a prominent Islamic scholar and journalist. Influenced by modernist ideas, he founded the Urdu newspaper Al-Hilal in Calcutta, which was banned by British authorities. Azad was a key figure in India’s independence movement, actively participating in the Khilafat Movement and aligning with Mahatma Gandhi's civil disobedience efforts, including the Dandi March and Quit India Movement. He served as president of the Indian National Congress twice and opposed the partition of India during independence negotiations. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he contributed to discussions on national language and education. Post-independence, he became the education minister, promoting cultural exchange through the Indian Council for Cultural Relations. Azad passed away on February 22, 1958, and was posthumously awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1992 for his significant contributions as a freedom fighter, journalist, and scholar.

name: Maulana Daud Ghaznavi
bio: Maulana Daud Ghaznavi was a member of the Constituent Assembly, serving from 14 July 1947 to  20 July 1949.

name: Maulana Muhammad Sayeed Masoodi
bio: Maulana Muhammad Sayeed Masoodi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Kashmir State.

name: Master Nand Lal
bio: Master Nand Lal was a member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab and was a part of the Provision Parliament from 1948 to 1952.

name: Masurya Din
bio: Masurya Din was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Mihir Lal Chattopadhyay
bio: Mihir Lal Chattopadhyay was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: Mirza Mohd. Afzal Beg
bio: Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg was an important leader in Jammu and Kashmir's political landscape. After studying law Aligarh Muslim University returned to Kashmir Sheikh Abdullah in protests against the Maharaja’s anti-democratic rule. Elected to the Kashmir Legislative Assembly in 1934, served as Minister for Public Works and Municipalities. Beg was elected to the Constituent Assembly of Jammu and Kashmir and contributed to the state's constitution from 1951 to 1956. After the 1975 Indira-Sheikh Accord, he served as Deputy Chief Minister but was asked to resign in 1978.

name: Mahomed Sheriff
bio: Mahomed Sheriff was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Mysore State.

name: Mandhata Singh
bio: Mandhata Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Eastern Rajputana States.

name: Manikya Lal Varma
bio: Manikya Lal Varma was a key Congress leader from Rajasthan. Varma served as Secretary of the Rajputana Pradesh Congress Committee in 1946 and was President of the Udaipur Praja Mandal in 1940. His commitment to the freedom movement led to multiple arrests for participating in Congress activities across Udaipur State between 1919 and 1942. After independence, he served as Prime Minister of the Rajasthan Union from April 1948 to April 1949. His efforts were pivotal in the integration and governance of the region.  He was awarded the Padma Bhushan by the Government of India in 1965.

name: Mohammad Ismail Khan
bio: Nawab Mohammad Ismail Khan, born in August 1884 in Meerut, was a prominent politician and activist associated with the All-India Muslim League and a close confidant of Muhammad Ali Jinnah. Ismail Khan played a vital role in the Indian independence movement, representing Muslim interests and leading various organisations, including the All-India Khilafat Committee. He was a founding member of Jamia Millia Islamia University and maintained correspondence with Jawaharlal Nehru, despite his ties to Jinnah. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provines, he opposed separate electorates for Muslims. After the partition, he chose to remain in India to advocate for Indian Muslims' rights.

name: Mohammad Tahir
bio: Mohammad Tahir was a lawyer from Bihar and an active member of the Indian National Congress. He served as a Member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly in 1937 and 1946. In 1946 he was elected to the Constituent Assembly representing Bihar. After independence, he represented Purnia, Bihar in the 2nd, 3rd, and 5th Lok Sabha.

name: Mohanlal Gautam
bio: Mohanlal Gautam was a notable freedom fighter from Aligarh. He left his studies in 1921 to join the Non-Cooperation Movement and later participated in national movements in Shahjahanpur and Hardoi. After earning a B.Ed. from National College, Lahore, he collaborated with leaders like Lala Lajpat Rai and became a member of Lok Sevak Sangh. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Mohan Lal Saksena
bio: Mohan Lal Saksena was a prominent leader in the Indian National Congress. Saksena actively participated in political movements and faced imprisonment multiple times. He held various leadership roles, including Secretary and President of the U.P. Congress Committee, and was a member of the Central Legislative Assembly. Saksena was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces on a Congress party ticket. Post-independence, he served as Secretary of the Congress Party in the Central Legislature and as Minister of Rehabilitation (1948-1950). Saksena also contributed to journalism as the Managing Director of the National Herald.

name: Mohan Sinha Mehta
bio: Mohan Sinha Mehta was a distinguished Indian statesman, educator, and diplomat. He founded the Vidya Bhawan Society in Udaipur in 1931, which played a crucial role in promoting education in the region. He served as the Finance Minister of Mewar State and Diwan of Banswara State. Mehta also held significant political positions, including Chief Minister of Mewar State and a representative to the Indian Constituent Assembly. After India’s independence, he represented the country diplomatically, serving as India's Ambassador to the Netherlands, High Commissioner to Pakistan, and Ambassador to Switzerland. He was a member of India’s delegation to the UN General Assembly in 1959 and participated in the Second Commonwealth Education Conference in 1961.

name: Mohd. Hifzur Rahman
bio: Mohd. Hifzur Rahman was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Motiram Baigra
bio: Motiram Baigra was a prominent leader from Jammu and Kashmir and a member of the Constituent Assembly. Baigra served as President of the Jammu Provincial National Conference, playing a key role in the region’s political movements. He was one of four representatives from Kashmir State in the Constituent Assembly. Following the accession of Jammu and Kashmir to India in 1947, Baigra worked alongside key leaders like Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah and Mirza Mohammad Afzal Beg in shaping the state's future.

name: Monomohan Das
bio: Monomohan Das was a medical practitioner and politician from West Bengal who played a notable role in India’s independence and post-independence political landscape. Born in Nawpara, Kolkata, Das graduated with an MBBS and worked as a physician and sanitary officer before joining the Indian National Congress in 1936. He was actively involved in the All India Forward Bloc led by Subhas Chandra Bose during the freedom movement. Elected to the Constituent Assembly, Das focused on minority rights, village panchayats, and the abolition of untouchability. Post-independence, he served in the Provisional Parliament and held multiple roles in the Lok Sabha, including Deputy Minister of Education and Scientific Research. Das dedicated himself to the upliftment of marginalised communities.

name: Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava
bio: Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava freedom fighter and member of the Indian National Congress. A prominent member of the Rajasthan Bar Council, he was elected as the member of the Constituent Assembly from Ajmer-Merwara. In the Assembly, he contributed to the discussions on the status of Chief Commissioners provinces (now known as Union Territories) in the Assembly. Bhargava was later elected as a Member of Parliament from Ajmer between 1952 and 1967.

name: Mukunda Bihari Mullick
bio: Mukunda Bihari Mullick was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: N. B. Khare
bio: N. B. Khare was an influential Indian political leader who played key roles in the governance of Central India during the pre-independence and post-independence periods. He served as a member of the Central Provinces Legislative Council from 1924 to 1930, and as a member of the Central Legislative Assembly from 1935 to 1937. Khare also represented the Central Provinces in the Legislative Assembly from 1937 to 1943. He was part of the Constituent Assembly of India from July 1947 to February 1948, contributing to the framing of the nation's Constitution. Additionally, he served as the Prime Minister of the former Alwar State from April 1947 to February 1948, and was a member of the first Lok Sabha after India’s independence. His political career was marked by his commitment to the democratic development of the nation.

name: N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar
bio: Narasimha Gopalaswami Ayyangar, a distinguished administrator, served in the Madras Civil Service before becoming the Prime Minister of Kashmir in 1937. Elected to the Council of States in 1943, Ayyangar was pivotal in the ‘Committee for the Indianization of Army’ and co-authored the Sapru Committee Report on Constitutional Reforms. Ayyangar was elected to the Constituent Assembly by the Madras Assembly, he was part of the Drafting Committee. He also was the chief architect of Article 370, which defined the special relationship of the state of Jammu and Kashmir with the Indian Union. He later served in Nehru's cabinet as Minister for Railways and Transport (1948-1952) and Defence Minister (1952-1953).

name: N. G. Ranga
bio: Nayakulu G. Ranga, an economist and social reformer, served as the economic advisor to the Madras Government (1929-30). He joined the All India Congress Committee in 1930 and was elected to the Central Legislative Assembly. Ranga was pivotal in abolishing the zamindari system in Andhra and founded the All India Kisan Congress in 1935. A follower of Gandhi, Ranga advocated for complete independence and opposed the Simon Commission and the First Round Table Conference. He was arrested in 1940 for supporting Subhash Chandra Bose. Elected to the Constituent Assembly, he contributed to discussions on decentralisation and emergency powers. After leaving Congress due to disagreements over land reforms, Ranga founded several political parties, including the Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party and the Swatantra Party.

documents.name: N. G. Ranga CAD Vol. I_20 January 1947
documents.src: ./documents/N. G. Ranga/N. G. Ranga CAD Vol. I_20 January 1947.pdf
documents.thumbnail: ./images/N. G. Ranga CAD Vol. I_20 January 1947.jpg

name: N. Madhava Rau
bio: Rau was a prominent Indian statesman, lawyer, and constitutional adviser. He served as Dewan of Mysore from 1941 to 1946 and participated in the Round Table Conferences and the drafting of the Government of India Act, 1935. Rao was a key figure in the Constituent Assembly, representing Orissa Princely States. As a member of the Drafting Committee, he contributed significantly to discussions on village panchayats and federalism. After independence, he served in the Provincial Parliament (1950-1951) before retiring from public life.

documents.name: N Madhava Rau CAD Vol._9 November 1948
documents.src: ./documents/N. Madhava Rau/N Madhava Rau CAD Vol._9 November 1948.pdf

name: Nagendra Singh
bio: Nagendra Singh was a distinguished Indian civil servant, scholar, and international law expert. He served in various key positions within the Indian government and represented India at the UN General Assembly multiple times. Singh held a prestigious role as a Judge at the International Court of Justice, eventually becoming its President for three years. He was also a member of the Constituent Assembly and made significant contributions to India's legal framework. Known for his expertise in international law, Singh was honored with the Padma Vibhushan, one of India's highest civilian awards, in recognition of his exceptional service.

name: Nandkishore Das
bio: Nandkishore Das was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Orissa.

name: Narhar Vishnu Gadgil
bio: Narhar Vishnu Gadgil was a freedom fighter, writer and politician from Maharashtra. He was a pioneer of various social reform movements in Maharashtra in the 1930s and was elected to the Constitutional Assembly from Bombay. He contributed to various debates around the national language of India, the federal set-up of the nation and the discussion on the budget estimates of the Assembly. In 1958 he was also appointed the Governor of Punjab.

name: Naziruddin Ahmad
bio: Naziruddin Ahmad was a distinguished lawyer, politician, and member of the Constituent Assembly of India. Born in Kulia, West Bengal, he studied law at Ripon Law College and practised at the Calcutta High Court and the Federal Court of India. Ahmad’s early political career included serving as Vice-Chairman of Burdwan Municipality and Secretary of the Burdwan Muhammedan Association, which promoted modern education within the Bengal Muslim community. Ahmad was also involved in the Praja movement and the Bengal Raiyat Association, advocating for labour rights and the plight of peasants Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Muslim League ticket, representing West Bengal, he actively contributed to debates on national language and minority reservations.

name: Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy
bio: Neelam Sanjeeva Reddi was a prominent leader from Andhra Pradesh. Reddi was elected to the Madras Legislative Assembly and became the Secretary of the Andhra Provincial Congress Committee in 1937. His active participation in the Quit India Movement led to multiple imprisonments between 1940 and 1945. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras on a Congress party ticket. He served as President of the Andhra Pradesh Congress Committee in 1951 and became the Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh in 1956. Reddi was elected the sixth President of India on July 25, 1977, becoming the youngest to hold the office and the only one elected unopposed.

name: N. C. Laskar
bio: Nibaran Chandra Laskar was an educationalist turned social reformer and politician. As a social reformer he actively worked for dalit upliftment in Assam. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam. He raised concerns about the representation of the Scheduled Castes in Assam after the Partition. Laskar was also later elected to the First Lok Sabha.

name: Omeo Kumar Das
bio: Omeo Kumar Das, popularly addressed as Lokanayak, was a social worker, Gandhian, educationist, writer and a former minister in the Government of Assam. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam.

name: O. P. Ramaswami Reddiyar
bio: O. P. Ramaswami Reddiyar a freedom fighter and politician from Madras. He served as the Premier of the Madras Presidency from 23 March 1947 to 6 April 1949 and was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He made several contributions towards social and legal reform in Madras as its Chief Minister. He became the first Chief Minister of Madras after independence, serving from March 23, 1947, to April 6, 1949. His tenure saw significant legal and social reforms, including the landmark Madras Temple Entry Authorisation Act of 1947. Reddiyar also promoted education by making elementary schooling compulsory, establishing advisory boards, and implementing adult education programs.

name: O. V. Alagesan
bio: O. V. Alagesan studied at Presidency College in Madras from 1928-1930 before abandoning his studies to join the freedom struggle. Active in the Salt Satyagraha, Civil Disobedience and Quit India he faced over three years of imprisonment. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras on a Congress Party ticket, Alagesan contributed to debates on bicameralism and preventive detention. served three terms in the Lok Sabha holding significant positions such as Union Minister for Transport and Railways and Minister of State for Irrigation and Power.

name: P. Govinda Menon
bio: Panampilli Govinda Menon was born on October 1, 1908, in Trichur, Kerala. He earned an Honours Degree in Physics and studied law, later practising in the courts. Menon entered politics early, participating in the Vaikom Satyagraha and joining the Prajamandalam and Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Cochin State Legislature multiple times and served as Chief Minister and Food Minister. As a representative of Travancore & Cochin in the Constituent Assembly, he contributed to discussions about princely states. After the merger of Travancore and Cochin, he held various positions, including Finance Minister and Law Minister under Indira Gandhi.

name: P. Kakkan
bio: P. Kakkan was a prominent Dalit leader and key figure in the temple entry movement. In 1939, he led five Dalits into the Meenakshi Amman temple, defying upper-caste opposition, a milestone for the Dalit rights movement. He was also active in the freedom struggle, participating in the Quit India Movement and serving 18 months in prison. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, Kakkan advocated for separate electorates and reservations. He later served in the Lok Sabha and as president of the Tamil Nadu Congress Committee.

name: P. K. Sen
bio: Sen was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar.

name: P. Kunhiraman
bio: P. Kunhiraman was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: P. L. Narasimha Raju
bio: P. L. Narasimha Raju was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: P. M. Velayudapani
bio: P. M. Velayudapani was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: P. S. Nataraja Pillai
bio: P.S. Nataraja Pillai was born in March 1891 in Alleppey, Kerala. He worked as a farmer and journalist and was elected to the Popular Assembly of Travancore in 1916, India’s first popularly elected legislature. He served in the Travancore Legislative Assembly from 1944 to 1947 and was part of the Travancore Constitution Reforms Committee in 1946. Pillai was associated with several political parties, including the Indian National Congress and the Praja Socialist Party. He promoted the Tamil language and directed the Travancore Tamil Sangam. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United State of Travancore & Cochin, where he contributed to the discussions on taxation. His legislative career continued in independent India, where he served in the Travancore-Cochin Legislative Assembly from 1948 to 1957.

name: P. S. Rau
bio: P. S. Rau was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Jodhpur

name: P. Subbarayan
bio: Paramasivan Subbarayan was an Indian politician, freedom fighter and diplomat. Initially a member of the Justice Party, Subbarayan switched to the Swarajya Party and joined the Indian National Congress in 1933. He served as the Chief Minister of Madras from 1926 to 1930 and was a member of the Madras Parliament from 1921 to 1949. Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress ticket, he contributed to debates on adult franchise, civil services, and official language. Later, he served in the Rajya Sabha (1954-57) and as Governor of Maharashtra in 1962. Subbarayan advocated for Dalit rights and proposed English as an official language for its accessibility to non-Hindi speakers.

name: P. T. Chacko
bio: P. T. Chacko, born on April 9, 1915, in Chirakkadavu, Kerala, was a prominent Congress leader and statesman. He graduated from St. Joseph’s College and earned a law degree from Trivandrum. Chacko abandoned his legal career to join the Indian independence movement in 1938, advocating for self-governance in Travancore and facing imprisonment five times. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly Travancore & Cochin, where he contributed to discussions on tax laws and the official language. After independence, he served in the Travancore and Kerala Legislative Assemblies and as a minister from 1960 to 1964. Notably, he established India’s first open prison in 1962. Chacko passed away on July 31, 1964, leaving a significant legacy in Kerala politics.

name: Paragi Lal
bio: Paragi Lal was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Phool Singh
bio: Phool Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Phulan Prasad Varma
bio: Phulan Prasad Varma was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar.

name: Pranlal Munshi
bio: Pranlal Thakurlal Munshi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Baroda State.

name: Prabhu Dayal Himatsingka
bio: Prabhu Dayal Himatsingka was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh
bio: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He served as the Chief Minister of West Bengal from 1947 to 1948 and again from 1967 to 1968.

name: Prafulla Chandra Sen
bio: Prafulla Chandra Sen was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He also served as the Chief Minister of West Bengal and a member of the Sixth Lok Sabha.

name: Pramatha Ranjan Thakur
bio: A leader of the Matua Mahasangh, Pramatha Ranjan Thakur was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Priyaranjan Sen
bio: Priyaranjan Sen was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Punjabrao S. Deshmukh
bio: Punjabrao S. Deshmukh, also known as Babusaheb Deshmukh, was an influential figure in India’s independence movement and a champion of farmers' rights. He founded the C. P. & Berar Farmers’ Association and actively participated in protests against untouchability. A prominent member of the Constituent Assembly, he contributed to discussions on citizenship and federalism. Post-independence, Deshmukh served as the Union Minister of Agriculture and was elected to the Lok Sabha for two terms between 1952 and 1962.

name: Purushottam Das Tandon
bio: Purushottamdas Tandon was a freedom fighter, politician and a prominent figure in the Indian National Congress. A lawyer, he shifted to full-time politics in 1921. He held several leadership roles, including President of the Kisan Sabha and member of the Congress Working Committee. He was involved in various movements, including the Non-Cooperation and Quit India movements, and founded the Hindu Rakshak Dal in 1947 to advocate for Hindu militarism. Tandon was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces. He contributed to debates on national language and the Objectives Resolution. He later served as President of the Congress, though his right-wing stance led to tensions with Jawaharlal Nehru. He was elected to the Lok Sabha in 1952 and nominated to the Rajya Sabha in 1956. Tandon received the Bharat Ratna in 1961 for his public service.

name: Purnima Banerji
bio: Purnima Banerji was a dedicated Congress leader and activist from the United Provinces. She actively participated in the Indian freedom struggle alongside notable figures like Sucheta Kripalani and Vijaylakshmi Pandit. Banerji was a member of the Congress Socialist Party and the Indian National Congress. As Secretary of the Allahabad City Congress Committee, she focused on rural outreach, organising meetings with farmers and trade unions. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, she contributed to debates on the Preamble, preventive detention, and Rajya Sabha qualifications.

name: Pushpendra Singhji
bio: Pushpendra Singhji was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the Central India States Group.

name: R. E. Platel
bio: R. E. Platel was a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: R. K. Shanmukham Chetty
bio: R.K. Shanmukham Chetty entered politics as a Councillor of the Coimbatore Municipality in 1917, initially joining the Indian National Congress before switching to the Justice Party. He was elected to the Madras Legislative Assembly in 1920 and the Central Legislative Assembly in 1923, where he introduced a bill to combat discrimination against the "untouchable" community. He even served as the Diwan of Cochin from 1935 to 1941, implementing administrative reforms and enhancing the Cochin Port. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, he later became India’s first Finance Minister, presenting the inaugural budget in November 1947.

name: R. M. Nalavade
bio: Nalavade was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bombay.

name: R. R. Diwakar
bio: Ranganath Ramachandra Diwakar was born in Dharwad, Karnataka, and he completed his M.A. and L.L.B from Fergusson College, Pune, before becoming a professor of English. He left teaching to join the Indian independence movement, founding the radical Kannada weekly Karmaveer, which led to his imprisonment in 1923. Diwakar actively participated in the Non-Cooperation Movement, Salt Satyagraha, and Quit India Movement. He advocated for the unification of Kannada-speaking regions and promoted Hindi and Khadi. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay, he later became the Union Minister of State for Information and Broadcasting and served as Governor of Bihar.

name: R. Sankar
bio: Sankar was born on 30 April 1909 in Kuzhikkalidavaka, Kerala. After completing his schooling, he studied law and began his career as a teacher. He became involved in the independence movement in the 1930s, advocating for social reforms and joining the Travancore State Congress. In 1944, he became the General Secretary of the Shree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam (SNDP). Sankar was elected to the Constituent Assembly but did not actively speak there. He served in the Travancore Legislative Assembly and later the Travancore-Cochin Assembly. Sankar led the Kerala Pradesh Congress Committee and played a significant role in the 1959 Liberation Struggle. He became the first Congress Chief Minister of Kerala in 1962 but resigned in 1964. He founded several educational institutions.

name: R.V. Dhulekar
bio: R.V. Dhulekar was a prominent Congress leader and activist from Jhansi, Uttar Pradesh. actively participated in India's independence movement, joining the Salt March and the Non-Cooperation Movement. He was a prominent advocate against untouchability and founded several educational institutions, including the Jhansi Ayurvedic University. He served as a Member of the Legislative Assembly (1936-1940) and held various leadership roles in the Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he debated key issues such as cow slaughter and Hindi as the official language. After independence, he served as a Member of Parliament (1952-1957) and Chairman of the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Council (1958-1964).

name: Radhavallabh Vijaivergiya
bio: Radhavallabh Vijaivergiya was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madhya Bharat.

name: Radhanath Das
bio: Radhanath Das was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Rafi Ahmed Kidwai
bio: Rafi Ahmed Kidwai was a key Congress leader and freedom fighter from United Provinces. Though he began an L.L.B. course, his legal studies were interrupted by his involvement in the Non-Cooperation Movement. He played an active role in the Khilafat Movement and was a close associate of Motilal Nehru. Kidwai served as a chief whip for the Swaraj Party in the Central Legislative Assembly (1926-1929). Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, he was a member of the Union Constitution, and Rules and Procedure Committees. He became India's first Communications Minister and inaugurated the first night air mail service.

name: Raghunandan Prasad
bio: Raghunandan Prasad was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar.

name: Raghu Vira
bio: Raghu Vira, born in Rawalpindi, was a linguist with advanced degrees from Lahore, London, and Leiden University. A dedicated member of the Congress Party, Vira aligned with the Hindu-Hindi extremist faction, opposing the Hindu Code Bill and advocating for Hindi supremacy. He established the International Academy of Indian Culture in 1932. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, he submitted amendments to prioritise Hindi over English in the Constitution and played a key role in translating it into Hindi.

name: Raghuraj Singh
bio: Raghuraj Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing the Eastern States Group 2.

name: Raj Bahadur
bio: Raj Bahadur was an active part of the freedom struggle and led the Indian Independence movement in the Bharatpur State (now Rajasthan). Active in politics from a young age, he was involved with the Hindustan Socialist Republican Army and served on the Central Advisory Committee of Bharatpur State. During the Indian independence movement, Bahadur led efforts in Bharatpur from 1940 to 1947, facing imprisonment twice for his activism. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Rajasthan, where he contributed to discussions on issues like property requisitioning and public health. Post-independence, Bahadur held various positions, including General Secretary of the Matsya Union Congress Committee and Deputy Minister of Communications. He served multiple terms in the Lok Sabha and held various ministerial roles, including Minister for Transport and Minister of Information & Broadcasting. He was also India's Ambassador to Nepal from 1968 to 1971 and actively promoted social welfare initiatives, particularly against forced labour.

name: Rajendra Prasad
bio: Rajendra Prasad was a prominent scholar, journalist, lawyer and freedom fighter. Prasad served as the President of the Constituent Assembly from 1946-1950. During the same time, he also chaired four committees of the Constituent Assembly. In 1950, Prasad became the first President of independent India. For his service to the nation he was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1962.

name: Raja Anand Chand
bio: Raja Anand Chand was a prominent Indian politician and author. He served as a member of the Constituent Assembly, the Lok Sabha, and the Rajya Sabha, contributing significantly to India's early political landscape. He was also the author of Bilaspur–Past, Present and Future, a work reflecting on the history and future of his region. His career in public service and his intellectual contributions have left a lasting impact on both national and regional politics.

name: Raj Krushna Bose
bio: Raj Krushna Bose was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Orissa.

name: Rajkumar Chakravarty
bio: Rajkumar Chakravarty was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Rajkumari Amrit Kaur
bio: Rajkumari Amrit Kaur, born into Punjab's Kapurthala royal family, became a prominent Indian freedom fighter and social reformer. Educated at Sherborne School and the University of Oxford, she became involved in social issues, advocating for women's rights and co-founding the All-India Women's Conference. A close associate of Gandhi, Kaur joined the Indian National Congress and actively participated in movements like the Salt Satyagraha and Quit India. As a member of the Constituent Assembly, she contributed to key discussions on fundamental rights and opposed provisions that could protect discriminatory practices. After Independence, Kaur became India's first Health Minister, she introduced the AIIMS Bill and championed education and health initiatives.

name: Ram Sahai
bio: Ram Sahai was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madhya Bharat. Later, he became a member of the Rajya Sabha, serving two terms. He had also served as the Speaker of the Madhya Bharat Legislative Assembly.

name: Ram Sahai Tiwari
bio: Ram Sahai Tiwari was an Indian politician and freedom fighter from Madhya Pradesh. As a member of the Indian National Congress, Tiwary served in the Constituent Assembly and the Provisional Parliament. He was also a member of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Lok Sabhas. His contributions to Indian politics and his service in various legislative capacities were significant during the formative years of post-independence India.

name: Ramnath Goenka
bio: Ramnath Goenka was born in Darbhanga, Bihar, and began his career as a dispatch vendor for the Free Press Journal after moving to Madras. In 1934 he acquired shares in the Indian Express and gained complete control two years later. Under his leadership, the newspaper emerged as a significant voice against British rule, famously responding to censorship during the Quit India movement by announcing its temporary shutdown to uphold journalistic integrity. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras on a Congress ticket, Goenka made key contributions, particularly regarding newspaper taxation. After India gained independence, he continued to lead the Indian Express, notably protesting against the Emergency by publishing blank columns and challenging pre-censorship orders in 1976.

name: Ramchandra Gupta
bio: Ram Chandra Gupta was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Ram Chandra Upadhyaya
bio: Ram Chandra Upadhyaya was a prominent Indian lawyer and freedom fighter associated with the Praja Mandal in Rajasthan. With a B.A. and LL.B., he actively participated in the Non-Cooperation Movement of 1931. As an influential figure, he served as the honorary editor of the only Hindi weekly in Alwar, 1946. Upadhyaya was imprisoned in 1946 and 1947 for his involvement in the independence struggle. He was a member of the Constituent Assembly and the Provisional Parliament, contributing to the early legislative framework of independent India.

name: Ramprasad Potai
bio: Ramprasad Potai was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar.

name: Rameshwar Prasad Sinha
bio: Rameshwar Prasad Sinha was an Indian statesman and a key figure in the independence movement. After practising law for six years, he left his practice to join Mahatma Gandhi's Non-Cooperation movement in 1921. Sinha was a member of the Constituent Assembly elected from Bihar.

name: Ratan Lal Malviya
bio: Ratan Lal Malviya was a distinguished lawyer and freedom fighter from Saugor, Madhya Pradesh. He practised law in Saugor District Court until 1935. Malviya was a leading figure in the Harijan movement, serving as the First Secretary of the Harijan Sewak Sangh. His commitment to labour rights was evident in his roles as Vice-President of the Indian National Coal Mine Workers’ Federation and President of the Chhattisgarh Colliery Workers’ Federation. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar

name: Rati Ram Gupta
bio: Rati Ram Gupta was honoured with the title ‘Deshbandhu’ by M. K.  Gandhi and Swami Shradhanand. He engaged with revolutionary leaders and campaigned for the separation of Haryana from Punjab, advocating for Dalit upliftment and the abolition of untouchability. Gupta served seven years in the Punjab Legislative Assembly and was profoundly impacted by the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, which led to his participation in the Quit India movement, leading to his arrest. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Delhi on a Congress ticket, he advocated for print media and sought for greater Delhi representation in Parliament. He co-founded the newspaper Rozana Tej and later acquired The Indian News Chronicle, which was renamed Indian Express after his death in 1951.

name: Ratnappa Bharamappa Kumbhar
bio: Ratnappa Bharamappa Kumbhar was a prominent Indian freedom fighter and politician from Kolhapur. A key figure in the Indian freedom struggle, Kumbhar was imprisoned and fined in 1939 for his involvement with the freedom movement. He was on the forefront of an agitation for dissolution of princely states. In the Constituent Assembly, Kumbhar represented Bombay States. He was later elected to the First Lok Sabha. Kumbhar was instrumental in co-operative movements and local development in Kolhapur, earning the Padma Shri in 1985 for social work.

name: Ravi Shankar Shukla
bio: Ravi Shankar Shukla began his political career during the 1899-1900 famine in Central Provinces, where his work as a famine officer gained him prominence. Influenced by Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Shukla joined the freedom struggle. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar on a Congress Party ticket. He advocated for Hindi as the national language and led a committee that pushed for the Constitution to be framed in Hindi, with English as a transitional option for five years. He opposed listing other Indian languages separately in the Constitution, believing it could undermine national stability. After Madhya Pradesh was formed in 1956, he briefly became its first Chief Minister.

name: Renuka Ray
bio: Renuka Ray was a prominent freedom fighter, social reformer, and advocate for women’s rights. Educated at the London School of Economics, she returned to India and joined the All India Women’s Conference, for which she also served as a president, where she championed women’s rights. In 1943, she was nominated to the Central Legislative Assembly as a representative for Indian women and later became a member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal. Post-independence, she was appointed Minister of Relief & Rehabilitation in West Bengal (1952-57) and a Lok Sabha MP from Malda. In 1959, she chaired the Renuka Ray Committee on Social Welfare and Welfare of Backward Classes, leaving a lasting impact on Indian social legislation.

name: Rohini Kumar Chaudhri
bio: Rohini Kumar Chaudhuri was a key leader in the Non-Cooperation movement in Assam. He served as a member of the Assam legislature from 1927 to 1945. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly of India. Chaudhuri spoke on number of issues in the Constituent Assembly like citizenship, discrimination, and untouchability.

name: Rustom K. Sidhva
bio: Rustom K. Sidhva began his career as a clerk in the Post Office in Karachi and later became the president of the Sind and Baluchistan Postmen’s Union in the early 1900s. A lifelong member of the Indian National Congress (INC), he served as General Secretary of the 45th INC in 1932. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, Sidhva represented the minority Parsi community. He actively participated in debates on minority rights, linguistic issues, and the role of religion in public life, reflecting his commitment to these issues.

name: S. H. Prater
bio: Stanley Henry Prater was a prominent British naturalist in India, known for his work with the Bombay Natural History Society and the Prince of Wales Museum, Bombay. While Prater did not engage in the Indian Independence Movement, he represented the Anglo-Indian community in legislative matters, serving as President of the Anglo-Indian and Domiciled European Association and a member of the Bombay Legislative Assembly from 1930 to 1947. He was recognized with the Order of the British Empire in 1943. In the Constituent Assembly, Prater represented the Anglo-Indian community and served on various committees but did not actively participate in debates. After India's independence, he moved to the UK.

name: S. M. Rizwan Allah
bio: S. M. Rizwan Allah was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: S. N. Mane
bio: S. N. Mane was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bombay.

name: S. Nagappa
bio: S. Nagappa joined the Congress in 1930 and won a general seat in the 1937 Madras Presidency elections representing Kurnool. He was dedicated to uplifting Scheduled Castes, establishing a free hostel for their students in Kurnool in 1938. Nagappa played a significant role in the India’s independence movement, being the first in Kurnool to offer individual satyagraha during the Civil Disobedience Movement Elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress Party ticket, he contributed to debates on minority representation and reservations. Later, he contested elections in 1952 and 1967 but faced defeats both times.

documents.name: S. Nagappa CAD Vol. III_2 May 1947

name: S. Nijalingappa
bio: S. Nijalingappa, a distinguished leader from Karnataka, played a crucial role in India’s freedom struggle and politics. He began his political career as President of the Chitradurga District Congress Committee in 1936, participating in the Forest Satyagraha, which cost him his bar licence. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay, he later became the first Chief Minister of Mysore (Karnataka), where he advanced irrigation and power projects and oversaw the resettlement of Tibetan refugees. In 1968, as President of the All-India Congress Committee, Nijalingappa led the Syndicate faction during its power struggle with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, leading to the Congress party split in 1969. He continued leading the Congress (O) faction until its merger with the Janata Party in 1977.

name: S. T. Dharmadhikari
bio: S. T. Dharmadhikari was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar.

name: S. V. Krishnamoorthy Rao
bio: S. V. Krishnamoorthy Rao was a distinguished Congress leader and advocate from Mysore. He founded the National Educational Society in Shimoga, contributing significantly to local education, and was active in various civil society organisations, including the Kannada Sahitya Parishad. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Mysore State, Rao contributed to discussions on Hindi's role and fiscal relations between the Union and States. Post-independence, he served on key committees, including finance and state trading, and was the first Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.

name: Sachchidananda Sinha
bio: Sachchidananda Sinha was an influential lawyer, parliamentarian, and journalist. Early in his career, Sinha was active in the Indian National Congress, holding the position of secretary from 1899 to 1920, and participated in the Home Rule League Movement. He served as the interim President of the Constituent Assembly of India. He is also recognized as one of the key architects behind the modern state of Bihar.

name: Sadashiv Kanoji Patil
bio: Sadashiv Kanoji Patil was a renowned Indian politician, journalist, and freedom fighter. Educated at St. Xavier's College, Bombay, and London University, Patil earned a diploma in journalism from the London School of Economics. He played a pivotal role in the Indian freedom struggle and led the Bombay Pradesh Congress Committee from 1946. He was elected as the Mayor of Bombay thrice. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay. Later he was also elected to the Lok Sabha in 1952 and became Union Minister for Food and Agriculture.

name: Saiyid Jafar Imam
bio: Saiyid Jafar Imam was a prominent Indian lawyer and politician from Bihar. A prominent leader in the Indian National Congress. He served as a Member of the Bihar Legislative Assembly. Imam later represented the state of Bihar in the Rajya Sabha.

name: Samaldas Laxmidas Gandhi
bio: Samaldas Laxmidas Gandhi was a journalist and a prominent leader of the India freedom struggle. He was a close follower of his uncle, Mahatma Gandhi. He played a key role in the integration of the erstwhile Princely State of Junagadh into India, heading the "Aarzi Hukumat" or Temporary Government of the princely state. A committed journalist, he founded the newspaper ‘Vande Mataram’. He was the sole member of the Constituent Assembly from Junagadh.

name: Sarat Chandra Bose
bio: Sarat Chandra Bose was an eminent lawyer and freedom fighter. He was elected to the Central Legislative Assembly in 1946 and served as the Leader of Opposition. He was the Minister for Works, Mines, and Power in the Interim Government of India. He also became a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal but resigned due to ideological differences.

name: Sarangdhar Das
bio: Sarangdhar Das was a prominent leader from Odisha, known for his contributions to both the Indian independence movement and the upliftment of marginalised communities. After studying at the Tokyo Institute of Technology and the University of California, Berkeley, Das returned to India and joined the Socialist Party, leading the All-Orissa States' Peoples' Movement, advocating for responsible governance in Princely States and working for the upliftment of tribal and lower caste communities. He served as President of the Orissa and Central Provinces States Regional Council (1946-1947) and was a member of the All-India Congress Committee. Elected to the Constituent Assembly representing the Orissa States, his interventions focused on state’s governance. He later served in the Orissa Legislative Assembly between 1946-49.

name: Sarangdhar Sinha
bio: Sarangdhar Sinha was an Indian legislator, parliamentarian, and academic from Bihar. He actively participated in the Civil Disobedience Movement from 1930, playing a key role in the Salt Satyagraha and the Quit India Movement. Sinha was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He was elected again to the first and second Lok Sabha as a Member of Parliament from Patna.

name: Sardar Baldev Singh
bio: Sardar Baldev Singh joined the Akali Party and worked with Sikh leader Tara Singh. He was elected to the Punjab Provincial Assembly in 1937 and served as the Development Minister from 1942 to 1946. Singh represented the Sikh community in negotiations with the Cripps Mission in 1942 and the Cabinet Mission in 1946, opposing partition and advocating for minority safeguards. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punja. Post-independence, Singh became India's first Defence Minister in the interim government under Jawaharlal Nehru, overseeing security and relief during partition.

name: Sardar Bhopinder Singh Man
bio: Sardar Bhopinder Singh Man was a prominent Sikh leader. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: Sardar Gian Singh Rarewala
bio: Sardar Gian Singh Rarewala was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Patiala & East Punjab States Union (PEPSU). He also served as the Chief Minister of PEPSU

name: Sardar Hukam Singh
bio: Sardar Hukam Singh, a lawyer in Montgomery, actively engaged in the freedom struggle, facing arrest in 1923 for anti-Simon Commission protests and again in 1924 for the Gurdwara Reforms Movement. He entered politics through the Shiromani Akali Dal and led the Montgomery Singh Sabha as President for three years. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab on an Akali Dal ticket. Singh also served as a Puisne Judge in the Kapurthala High Court. In the Assembly, he focused on advocating safeguards for the Sikh community and minority reservations. Singh served in the First Lok Sabha from PEPSU, becoming Deputy Speaker in 1956 and later representing Bhatinda. In 1962, he was elected Speaker of the Lok Sabha, the first Sikh to hold the position. In 1967, he was appointed as the Governor of Rajasthan.

name: Sardar Jaidev Singh
bio: Sardar Jaidev Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Patiala.

name: Sardar Jogendra Singh
bio: Sardar Jogendra Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces.

name: Sardar Ranjit Singh
bio: Sardar Ranjit Singh, was a Member of Constituent Assembly from Patiala & East Punjab States Union.

name: Sardar Singhji of Khetri
bio: Sardar Singhji of Khetri was a prominent Indian statesman, educated barrister, and philanthropist from Rajasthan. He was called to the Bar by the Honourable Society of the Middle Temple, London, in 1942. He served on several key committees, including the Jaipur State Constitutional Reforms Committee (1942), the Post-War Reconstruction Committee (1943), and the Franchise and Delimitation Committee (1944). He was a member of the Jaipur Legislative Council (1945) and the State Rural Development Board. Elected to the Constituent Assembly in 1947, he played a role in shaping India’s Constitution. He also served as a member of the Standing Committee for Communications and was part of the Provisional Parliament (1950–52) and the Rajya Sabha (1952–56). Notably, he was appointed as India’s Ambassador to Laos from 1958 to 1961.

name: Sardar Sochet Singh
bio: Sardar Sochet Singh was a Member of Constituent Assembly from Patiala & East Punjab States Union.

name: Sarojini Naidu
bio: One of the fifteen women members of the Constituent Assembly, Sarojini Naidu was an eminent poet and freedom fighter. She is known for her prominent role in the freedom struggle and the establishment of the Women’s India Association. Naidu served as the Governor of United Provinces from 1947 to 1949. She died on 02 March 1949.

documents.name: Sarojini Naidu CAD Vol. IV_22 July 1947
