name: Satis Chandra Samanta
bio: Satis Chandra Samanta was a distinguished leader in the Indian independence movement and a dedicated public servant. Despite beginning his studies at Bengal Engineering College, Samanta chose to abandon his education to focus on the struggle for India's freedom. He became an active member of the Indian National Congress, rising to prominence as the President of the Tamluk Congress Committee. During the Quit India Movement, he was instrumental in establishing the Tamralipta Jatiya Sarkar (Tamralipta National Government) in 1942, serving as its leader until his arrest in 1943. This parallel government, which operated until 1944, undertook various initiatives including disaster relief, educational support, and the formation of an armed Vidyut Vahini. Following India's independence, Samanta's commitment to public service continued as he served as a Member of the Lok Sabha for 25 years, from 1952 to 1977.

name: Satish Chandra
bio: Satish Chandra was an Indian politician and freedom fighter from Bareilly, Uttar Pradesh. He earned degrees in agriculture and economics before becoming a businessman. Chandra joined the Indian National Congress in 1935 and was actively involved in trade unions and Dalit welfare, resulting in his imprisonment three times during the freedom struggle. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces. He founded the Indian Youth Congress in 1949 and served as Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister in 1951. Chandra held key roles as deputy minister in defence, production, and commerce, later turning to business, chairing the BIC Group of Industries and Indian Airlines Corporation.

name: Satya Ranjan Baksi
bio: Satya Ranjan Baksi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Satyanarayan Sinha
bio: Satyanarayan Sinha was a lawyer turned politician. He entered politics by joining the Congress Party in 1924. He became a member of the Bihar Legislative Council in 1926 and the Central Legislative Assembly in 1934. Sinha was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He served as the Chief Whip of the Congress Assembly Party. He was elected to the first three Lok Sabhas, during which he served on several portfolios including Minister of Parliamentary Affair, Information and Broadcasting as well as Communications.

name: Seth Govind Das
bio: Seth Govind Das was an active member of the Indian National Congress, actively participated in key movements such as the Non-Cooperation Movement, the protests against the Simon Commission, the Civil Disobedience Movement, and the Quit India Movement. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar, where he contributed to debates on issues like the ban on cow slaughter, the national language, and the national anthem. A prominent Parliamentarian, he served as the pro-tem speaker in the Second, Third, Fourth, and Fifth Lok Sabhas.

name: Shambhu Nath Shukla
bio: Shambhu Nath Shukla was a prominent Indian politician and freedom fighter from Vindhya Pradesh. A dedicated member of the Indian National Congress, Shukla was integral to India's independence movement, enduring imprisonment for his activism. He served as a member of the Indian Constituent Assembly and the Provisional Parliament, later representing Vindhya Pradesh in the Rajya Sabha from 1952 to 1960. Shukla was the Chief Minister of Vindhya Pradesh from 1952 to 1956, overseeing its transition into Madhya Pradesh. He also held the position of Forest Minister in Pandit Ravishankar Shukla's government and was an MP for Rewa from 1967 to 1971.

name: Shankarrao Deo
bio: Shankarrao Deo was a freedom fighter and politician from Maharashtra. A dedicated Gandhian, he participated in the Bombay Home Rule movement, protests against Simon Commission, Salt Satyagraha and Quit India movement. He served as the first Secretary of the Maharashtra Pradesh Congress Committee and later as the General Secretary of the Congress Party from 1946 to 1950. Deo was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar, where he contributed to discussions on national language and adult franchise.

name: Shantanu Kumar Das
bio: Shantanu Kumar Das was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Orissa.

name: Shantilal H. Shah
bio: Shantilal H. Shah was a prominent Indian political leader who served as a member of the Bombay Legislative Council and the Maharashtra Legislative Assembly. He was also a member of the Constituent Legislative Assembly for a brief period. Throughout his career, he held several key ministerial positions, including Minister of Labour, Public Health, Education, and Law and Judiciary in the Maharashtra government. Additionally, Shah was elected to the 4th Lok Sabha, contributing significantly to the development and governance of the region.

name: Sheikh Mahoob Elahi
bio: Sheikh Mahoob Elahi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah
bio: Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah, popularly known as Sher-e-Kashmir an important leader in Kashmiri politics and was key to Jumma and Kashmir’s accession into India. He led the "Quit Kashmir" movement. Post-independence, he became Prime Minister of Jammu and Kashmir in 1948, where he implemented significant land reforms and participated in drafting the state constitution. He was elected as member of the Constituent Assembly from Kashmir State. In 1948 he also became the first elected Prime Minister of Kashmir.

name: Shibban Lal Saksena
bio: Shibban Lal Sakena, born on July 13, 1906, in Agra, was educated in Kanpur and earned degrees from the University of Allahabad and Agra University. He became a professor of Mathematics and Philosophy at St. Andrew’s College, Gorakhpur. Inspired by Mahatma Gandhi, Saxena dedicated himself to socio-economic causes and the welfare of labourers, leading various trade unions. He was arrested multiple times, serving a total of 13 years in prison for his involvement in the independence movement, including a decade for the 'Gorakhpur Conspiracy.' Elected to the Constituent Assembly from the United Provinces, he advocated for banning cow slaughter and addressing intoxicants. Saxena later served in the first, second, and fifth Lok Sabhas and represented India at several labour conferences.

name: Sita Ram S. Jajoo
bio: Sita Ram S. Jajoo was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madhya Bharat.

name: Somnath Lahiri
bio: Somnath Lahiri was a prominent Communist leader who represented Bengal in the Constituent Assembly from 1946 to 1947. He also served as a member of the West Bengal State Assembly and held ministerial positions in the state government. Lahiri was a prolific writer and he founded and edited the magazine "Swadhinata.”

name: Sri Krishna Sinha
bio: Krishna Sinha, an influential figure in Bihar played a pivotal role in the Non-Cooperation, Satyagraha, and Civil Disobedience movements. He was elected as a member of the Legislative Council in 1927. He was appointed as the Premier of Bihar in 1946 a post he resigned in protest against British actions in World War II. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar, Sinha actively participated in discussions on the Objective Resolutions introduced by Jawaharlal Nehru.

name: Sri Narayan Mahta
bio: Sri Narayan Mahta was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bihar. He was a member of the Indian National Congress. He began his political career as a member of the Bihar Legislative Council from 1930 to 1936, and later served in the Council of State from 1937 to 1947. He contributed to nation-building by serving in the Provisional Parliament and as a Rajya Sabha member.

name: Sucheta Kripalani
bio: Sucheta Kripalani was a prominent Indian freedom fighter, politician, and the first woman Chief Minister of an Indian state. Born in Ambala, she graduated from Indraprastha College and taught at Banaras Hindu University. After marrying Acharya Kripalani in 1936, she joined the Congress Party in 1938, serving in its Foreign Department and Women's Section. Active in the independence movement, she participated in the Quit India Movement, evading arrest until she was detained in 1944. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces, she contributed to the presentation of the first Indian flag. As one of the first women parliamentarians in independent India, she served in various legislative roles and became the first female Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh from 1963 to 1967. A staunch Gandhian, she was involved in refugee rehabilitation during Partition and represented India in numerous international delegations.

name: Sufi Abdul Hamid Khan
bio: Sufi Abdul Hamid Khan was a member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: Sunder Lal
bio: Sunder Lal was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Surendra Mohan Ghose
bio: Surendra Mohan Ghose was a prominent revolutionary-turned-politician from Bengal. Born in Mymensingh, he joined the Jugantar party as a teenager, engaging in armed struggle for independence. Imprisoned multiple times, including alongside Subhas Chandra Bose, Ghose spent nearly twenty-three years in jail. After his release, he joined the Indian National Congress and shifted towards non-violent resistance, leading the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee from 1939 to 1950. Ghose was elected to the Constituent Assembly on a Congress ticket from West Bengal. After independence, he served as Chairman of the House Committee of the Provincial Parliament and was elected to the first Lok Sabha. He was also involved with All-India Radio in his later years.

name: Suresh Chandra Banerjee
bio: Suresh Chandra Banerjee was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal.

name: Sures Chandra Majundar
bio: Sures Chandra Majundar was member of the Constituent Assembly from West Bengal.

name: Swetachalapathi Ramakrishna Ranga Rao
bio: Swetachalapathi Ramakrishna Ranga Rao, of Bobbili was a member of Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: Syamanandan Sahaya
bio: Syamanandan Sahaya during his early days served as Chairman of local committees on agriculture, education, and labour. Between 1943-46 he was the President of the Bihar Chamber of Commerce and Industries and the General Secretary of the Bihar Land Owners Association. Sahaya was one of few independent candidates in the Constituent Assembly. He actively participated in the discussions on the importance of protection of private property of citizens, fundamental rights and financial adjustments between the provinces.

name: Syama Prasad Mookerjee
bio: Syama Prasad Mookerjee was a prominent politician, academic, and member of the Constituent Assembly from Calcutta. Initially a member of the Indian National Congress, even elected to the Bengal state legislature as its member, Mookerjee resigned later due to ideological differences. He served as Vice-Chancellor of Calcutta University and became a key figure in Bengal politics, leading the opposition and later heading the All-India Hindu Mahasabha. In the Constituent Assembly, he was a vocal advocate for minority rights, regional languages, and opposed the Muslim League’s exclusion from the Assembly. Post-independence, Mookerjee founded the Bharatiya Jana Sangh and fiercely opposed Article 370. He died in custody in Kashmir in 1953.

name: Syed Muhammad Sa'adulla
bio: Syed Muhammad Sa'adulla was a lawyer and prominent leader of the Muslim League in Assam. He was one of the 28 Muslim League members who attended the proceedings of the Constituent Assembly. Notably, he was the sole Muslim League member on the Drafting Committee.

name: Tajamul Husain
bio: Tajamul Husain educated in England, rose to the position of Special Public Prosecutor in Muzaffarpur (1928) and Patna (1930). He was later appointed as First-Class Magistrate. Elected to the Bihar Legislative Assembly in 1935, Hussain advocated for the abolition of seat reservations for communities. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bihar, where he actively participated in debates on freedom of religion, emergency proclamations, and reservations.

name: Tanguturi Prakasam
bio: Tanguturi Prakasam, after studying in the UK and practising law at the Madras High Court, was inspired by Indian nationalists like Dadabhai Naoroji and Bipin Chandra Pal. He abandoned his legal career to focus on the freedom struggle and founded the newspaper Swarajya to promote Satyagraha and mass participation in the freedom struggle. Prakasam actively participated in protests against the Simon Commission and led the Salt March in Madras, earning him the title ‘Andhra Kesari’. He was elected to the Madras provincial legislature in 1937, where he served as Revenue Minister and later became Chief Minister in 1946. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, he addressed important issues such as village republics and Governor's discretionary powers. Post independence, Prakasam worked towards the creation of the state of Andhra Pradesh on linguistic lines.

name: T. A. Ramalingam Chettiar
bio: T. A. Ramalingam Chettiar was a key figure in the cooperative societies movement in Madras province. He practised law at the Madras High Court and served as Chairman of the Bar Council of Madras. His political career included roles as Chairman of the District Board of Coimbatore, Coimbatore Municipality, and a member of the Madras Legislative Council from 1921 to 1939. Chettiar founded the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Federation and established the Ramalingam Co-operative Training Institute. Elected to the Constituent Assembly in 1946, he contributed to debates on language and cottage industries. He was later elected to the Parliament from Coimbatore in 1951.

name: T. Channiah
bio: T. Channiah was a significant figure in India’s independence movement and a member of the Constituent Assembly. Channiah emerged as a strong advocate for the rights of marginalised communities. He served as General Secretary of the Mysore State Aikya Karnataka Sangha (1940–46) and led the Scheduled Castes Federation in Mysore (1946). Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Mysore State, Channiah advocated for the rights of the depressed classes and their socio-economic upliftment. He insisted on speaking in Kannada to highlight regional representation. He also contributed to the debates on social and economic equity. He joined the Indian National Congress in 1948 and later represented Karnataka in the Rajya Sabha.

name: T. J. M. Wilson
bio: T. J. M. Wilson was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: T. Siddalingaiya
bio: T. Siddalingaiya was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Mysore State.

name: T. T. Krishnamachari
bio: Tiruvallur Thattai Krishnamachari an entrepreneur and politician from Madras Presidency. In 1928, he founded TTK Company Ltd., an indenting agency, before transitioning to full-time politics. He became a member of the Madras Legislative Assembly in 1937 and the Central Legislative Assembly in 1942. Elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras, Krishnamachari contributed significantly as a member of the Drafting Committee, dedicating over 4,000 hours to discussions on issues like freedom of speech and emergency provisions. He later served as Central Minister for Iron and Steel (1955-1957) and briefly as Finance Minister, introducing vital tax reforms.

name: T. Vijayaraghavacharya
bio: T. Vijayaraghavacharya was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Udaipur.

name: Thakur Chhedilal
bio: Thakur Chhedilal was a prominent figure in the Civil Disobedience Movement, where he played a key role in mobilising farmers from Mungeli in present-day Chattisgarh. In the 1937 provincial elections, he was elected to the Central Provinces Legislative Assembly. He was later elected to the Constituent Assembly from Central Provinces and Berar.

name: Thakur Das Bhargava
bio: Thakur Das Bhargava was a lawyer and politician from Punjab. In 1926, he entered politics as a member of the Central Legislative Assembly. He was part of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Delegation to England in 1948 and also chaired the Jail Reforms Committee for East Punjab. He also served on the Advisory Committees on Defence and Finance for the Government of India. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab, he contributed to debates on cow slaughter, the Preamble, and the Vice President's role.

name: Thakur Krishna Singh
bio: Thakur Krishna Singh was a member of the Constituent Assembly representing Residuary States.

name: Uday Chand Mahtab
bio: Uday Chand Mahtab was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Bengal. He was the last ruler of the erstwhile zamindar estate of Burdwan Raj.

name: Upendranath Barman
bio: Upendranath Barman studied law at University Law College, Calcutta, and began his public career as Vice-Chairman of Jalpaiguri Municipality. A member of the Indian National Congress, he served in the Bengal Legislative Assembly and held ministerial positions in the Congress Coalition Cabinet. Barman’s personal experiences with caste discrimination fueled his advocacy for the rights of backward classes. He was deeply involved in the Kshatriya Samiti, working towards the abolition of the zamindari system and promoting education for social upliftment. As a member of the Constituent Assembly, he actively contributed to debates on minority rights. Barman also authored books on the Rajbanshi community's history and literature.

name: U. Srinivas Mallayya
bio: U. Srinivas Mallayya was a prominent Indian politician and architect from Mangalore. After completing his education in Mangalore, he joined the freedom movement at 18, inspired by Mahatma Gandhi, and faced imprisonment as a Satyagrahi. Mallayya's political career began as the Secretary of the District Congress Committee, later serving as President from 1937 to 1950 and becoming a member of the All India Congress Committee. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras. He was later elected to the Lok Sabha in 1952 and served multiple terms, holding key positions, including Deputy Chief Whip of the Congress Parliamentary Party.

name: Vallabhbhai J Patel
bio: Vallabhbhai Jhaverbhai Patel was one of the most prominent leaders of the freedom movement. His political journey began in 1917 with his election to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation, where he implemented major reforms in sanitation and education. As a prominent leader in the Indian independence movement, Patel was actively involved in the Non-Cooperation, Satyagraha, and Quit India movements, facing arrests for his activism. He served as President of the Indian National Congress during the 1931 Karachi session, where the historic Karachi Resolution was passed. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Bombay. Patel focused on fundamental and minority rights during the constitution-making process. As India’s first Home Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, he played a crucial role in integrating the 565 princely states into the Union and organised relief efforts for refugees. His leadership earned him the title "Iron Man of India."

documents.name: Sardar Patel CAD Vol._12 October 1949
documents.src: ./documents/Vallabhbhai J Patel/Sardar Patel CAD Vol._12 October 1949.pdf

name: V. C. Kesava Rao
bio: V. C. Kesava Rao was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Madras on a Congress Party ticket. He advocated for social justice, while emphasising on equality among citizens, calling for a ban on untouchability and the abolition of the zamindari system. He also highlighted the need for fair compensation for land acquired by the government for public purposes. Post-independence, Rao served in the Provisional Parliament from 1950 to 1952 and was later elected to the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly in 1967. He served two tenures in the Rajya Sabha, from 1962 to 1967 and again from 1974 to 1986. In 1971, he was appointed President of the Andhra Pradesh Congress Committee.

name: Venkatesh Narayan Tivari
bio: Venkatesh Narayan Tivary was born in 1890 in Kanpur. A journalist by profession, he edited the Hindi weekly Abhyudaya and newspapers like Maryada and Bharat. Tivary was actively involved in famine relief efforts and provided support to victims of martial law in Punjab. His commitment to India's independence saw him imprisoned multiple times for participating in Congress movements against British rule. He held various political roles, including General Secretary of the Uttar Pradesh Congress Committee, a member of the UP Legislative Council, and the UP Legislative Assembly, along with serving as Parliamentary Secretary to the Premier of Uttar Pradesh. Elected to the Constituent Assembly  form United Provinces, Tivary contributed to committees focused on police and public health reorganisation and was part of the Criminal Tribes Act Enquiry Committee. He later served in the first Lok Sabha representing the Kanpur cum Farrukhabad constituency.

name: V. I. Munishwamy Pillay
bio: V. I. Munishwamy Pillay was an activist committed to the empowerment of Scheduled Castes who faced economic challenges that limited his formal education. He began his career as a clerk before establishing his own business in 1925. Pillay served on the Madras Legislative Council in 1926 as a representative of the Depressed Classes and played a significant role in the All India Depressed Classes Federation, including signing the Poona Pact in 1932. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from the Madras Presidency on a Congress party ticket, where he advocated for the welfare of the Dalit community. Following independence, he served as a cabinet minister in the Provisional Parliament under Jawaharlal Nehru.

name: V. Nadimuthu Pillai
bio: V. Nadimuthu Pillai was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: V. T. Krishnamachari
bio: V. T. Krishnamachari joined the Indian Civil Services, becoming the Diwan of the State of Baroda from 1927 to 1944 and serving on the Reserve Bank Committee from 1930 to 1934. He held various significant positions, including Chairman of the Committee of Ministers in the Chamber of Princes and Prime Minister of the State of Jaipur. He represented the United States of Rajasthan in the Constituent Assembly. Post-independence, Krishnamachari was instrumental in establishing the Panchayati Raj system and served as the Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission from 1953 to 1960. He focused on agricultural development and community programs, believing in the importance of villages in India’s democratic framework. He also became the first chairman of the Indian Institute of Public Administration (1954-1963).

name: V. Subramaniam
bio: V. Subramaniam was a member of the Constituent Assembly from Madras.

name: Vinayakrao B. Vaidya
bio: Vinayakrao Balashankar Vaidya was a prominent Indian lawyer and political leader from Rajpipla, Bombay. An influential figure in local politics, Vaidya served as Secretary of the Rajpipla State Congress Committee and was a key member of the Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee. He founded the Rajpipla State Peoples Conference in 1927 and served as its President in 1947. He represented Bombay States in the Constituent Assembly.

name: Vinayak Sitaram Sarwate
bio: Vinayak Sitaram Sarwate was a prominent Indian freedom fighter, political leader, and author from Indore. Educated at Holkar College in Indore and Law College, Aligarh, Sarwate practised law in the High Court of Indore State. A key figure in the Indian independence movement, Sarwate served as Chief Secretary of the first Praja Mandal Conference in Indore in 1923. Post independence, Sarwate was appointed Minister of Education in the Indore State in 1948. He was elected as member of the Constituent Assembly from Madhya Bharat. Sarwate was awarded the Padma Bhushan in 1966 for his contribution to education and literature.

name: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit
bio: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit was born in the illustrious Nehru household as Swarup Nehru, and was the younger sister of Jawaharlal Nehru. She developed an interest in politics from a young age and was mesmerised by the oratory of Sarojini Naidu and Annie Besant. Inspired by these women, she began volunteering for the Congress and eventually became involved in the independence movement. She set up various weaving centres in villages, led processions, gave speeches and organised protests as part of the nationalist movement. After her marriage, she took on the name Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit. /n Vijaya Lakshmi understood gender problems to be structural and acknowledged the importance of systematic change, especially in the education system, which she tried to implement while she was President of the All India Women’s Conference from 1941-42. She also travelled internationally, visiting the USA in a bid to raise awareness about the Indian independence movement and garner the support of the American public through various public meetings, speeches, press interviews, and meetings with government officials. Her exemplary tour led to her being assigned the head of the Indian Legislation to the UN General Assembly where she led India’s case against South Africa’s mistreatment and denial of human rights to Indians residing there. /n Soon after her return to India, she was elected to the Constituent Assembly where she said, ‘It was my privilege in 1937 to move the first resolution… in my province, demanding a Constituent Assembly to draw up a Constitution for an Independent India. Today, ten years later, the Constituent Assembly is meeting here. This is a historic milestone in our progress towards freedom and yet, Sir, freedom remains just a little beyond our grasp’. /n In August 1947, she was appointed as India’s ambassador to the USSR and moved to Moscow for two years before shifting to the USA. She was then appointed as the High Commissioner of the United Kingdom, and in 1953, she was elected as the President of the United Nations General Assembly, becoming the first woman and only Indian to occupy the office at the time. She was awarded the Padma Vibhushan for Civil Service in 1962.

name: Vishwambhar Dayal Tripathi
bio: Vishwambhar Dayal Tripathi was a member of the Constituent Assembly from United Provinces.

name: Yashwant Rai
bio: Yashwant Rai was member of the Constituent Assembly from East Punjab.

name: Yudhisthir Mishra
bio: Yudhishthir Mishra was an Indian politician and advocate from Odisha. Mishra became involved in student activism as Secretary of the Bihar Students Federation (1940-41). He practised law at the Orissa High Court and later joined the Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Orissa States. There he spoke on the struggles of people in the Princely States. He continued his political work as the President of the Patna State Krushak Party, the Patna State District Congress Committee, and a member of the Orissa Pradesh Congress Committee and Orissa State Assembly.

name: Y. S. Parmar
bio: Y. S. Parmar was a prominent politician from Himachal Pradesh, representing it in the Constituent Assembly. He served as the Chief Minister of Himachal Pradesh from July 1963 to January 1977. He was also a member of the Provisional Parliament of India from 1950 to 1952 and the Second Lok Sabha.
